urn:contentItem:60GJ-6W71-F03R-N55C-00000-00Famed economist Mohamed El-Erian says its a 'real question mark' whether the massive valuations of tech giants like Amazon make 'sense' anymore2020-07-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisFamed economist Mohamed El-Erian says its a 'real question mark' whether the massive valuations of tech giants like Amazon make 'sense' anymoreShalini Nagarajan

Jul 31, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Famed economist Mohamed El-Erian said in a Thursday interview that he doubts the overall valuation of US tech companies.While he accepted that their robust balance sheets and positive cash flow will ensure continued outperformance, he said he doesn't know "whether the valuation still makes sense to tell you the truth."El-Erian's comments came a day after congressional testimony from CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Alphabet to address how they are handling antitrust challenges.The economist also said the latest US GDP data points to worrying signs of "leveling off" as there are continuous disagreements over what to do with the next COVID-19 relief package.Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[1]. Mohamed El-Erian said in an interview with Yahoo Finance[2] that the overall valuation of US tech companies is a "real question mark" to him."The theme underlying the performance of the Nasdaq, I like. The valuation I'm less excited about," he said on Yahoo's show "On the Move."El-Erian highlighted the tech giants' strong balance sheets, robust cash flow, competent management, and an increase in demand for their services during the COVID-19 outbreak, and suggested they would continue to do well and outperform."But it's the overall valuation that's the real question mark for me," the economist said."I can see them continuing to outperform because they have both the resiliency and agility to manage this economy.

I just don't know whether the valuation still makes sense to tell you the truth."El-Erian's comments came a day after CEOs of Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google's parent Alphabet testified before Congress[3] on matters related to whether the big four have an unfair advantage over the rest of the sector. Read More: The creator of the first pure-play space ETF told us 3 reasons why now is the perfect time to invest in the arena — including his bet on companies already raking in revenues from there[4]The leaders addressed how they're handling antitrust challenges put forth by regulators.Tech stocks[5], which have outperformed consistently this year, held onto gains through the start of the hearing.In the same interview, El-Erian also commented on the state of the US economy.Calling the shape of economic recovery a "square root" one, El-Erian said an initial improvement in jobless claims is beginning to level off and that's worrisome because of sensitivities to "policy slippage."Data published Thursday by the Commerce Department showed GDP contracted by 33%[6] at an annualized rate, officially marking the worst GDP slump for the American economy.He said that household savings shot up in the second quarter when people received stimulus checks and attempted to deal with uncertainty brought on by COVID-19, while pointing out that there is "continued disagreement" at Capitol Hill over what to do next with the relief package."We are going to see an increase in voluntary savings, even as jobs recover," he said.Read More: 200-plus money managers pay thousands to set eyes on Jim Osman's stock buy list. Here are 2 he says are set to soar — and an under-the-radar IPO to keep a watch on[7] Read the original article on Business Insider[8] [ 1]: https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet [ 2]: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1FNZqOc2Lp3ItICvNfD1DE-QdzalSyZfHaRnd3Y--rT0/edit# [ 3]: https://www.businessinsider.com/watch-live-congress-big-tech-antitrust-apple-google-facebook-amazon-2020-7 [ 4]: https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-in-space-reasons-for-bullish-outlook-ufo-2020-7 [ 5]: https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-news-today-indexes-fed-meeting-big-tech-testimony-2020-7-1029447460# [ 6]: https://www.businessinsider.com/us-q2-gdp-record-decline-coronavirus-pandemic-recession-lockdowns-economy-2020-7 [ 7]: https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-jim-osman-pinpoints-3-potential-winners-2020-7 [ 8]: https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-valuations-may-not-make-sense-mohamed-el-erian-2020-7

urn:contentItem:5S1M-3T21-DYTH-G29B-00000-00FAMILY RESEARCH COUNCIL TO HOST PANEL ON FREE SPEECH, PRIVACY IN THE AGE OF FACEBOOK, GOOGLE, TWITTER2018-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisFAMILY RESEARCH COUNCIL TO HOST PANEL ON FREE SPEECH, PRIVACY IN THE AGE OF FACEBOOK, GOOGLE, TWITTERStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, DC

The following information was released by the Family Research Council (FRC):

On April 17th, Family Research Council is hosting a lecture on the question of: Losing our voices: who owns free speech on the internet? In an era when 69 percent of American adults use social media platforms to express themselves, the free market powers of digital giants like Facebook, Google, and Twitter have collided with the free speech rights of citizen internet users. In the wake of a consistent pattern of censorship by tech companies of lawful but politically incorrect viewpointsparticularly those of conservatives and Christianswhat is the legal status of digital free expression? Is big tech entitled to the information of its platform users? And in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, can the tech giants be trusted to regulate themselves? What are the benefits and pitfalls of government intervention? And will Silicon Valley be the final arbiter of opinions and information in the virtual sphere?

WHO:

Rep. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.)

Craig Parshall, Special Counsel, American Center for Law and Justice

WHAT: Losing our voices: who owns free speech on the internet? lecture

WHEN: Tuesday April 17th at noon Eastern

WHERE: In person: 801 G Street, NW, Washington, D.C. 20001

Online: https://www.frc.org/events/losing-our-voices-who-owns-free-speech-on-the-internet

urn:contentItem:5W8B-KXT1-F03R-N4FP-00000-00FANGMAN Stocks Crushed by Potential 'Unprecedented, Wide-Ranging Probe' into Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisFANGMAN Stocks Crushed by Potential 'Unprecedented, Wide-Ranging Probe' into Google, Apple, Facebook, AmazonYves Smith

Jun 04, 2019( Naked Capitalism: http://www.nakedcapitalism.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Yves here. Who'd have thunk it? Curbing rentier capitalism would be bad for rentiers. It's only recently that more and more economic research and press interest about the cost of monopolies has taken the sheen off tech giants like Google and Amazon as it becomes increasingly obvious that their outsized results result from the abuse of market power, and not providing better services (if you think Google search circa 2019 can hold a candle to Google search circa 2009, I have a bridge I'd like to sell you).The one area of significant bipartisan distrust is big tech monopolies.

https://t.co/A3d9Qr9rmH[1] — Matt Stoller (@matthewstoller) June 3, 2019[2]By Wolf Richter, publisher of Wolf Street[3]. Originally published at Wolf Street[4] It's a rare moment in recent years that US government regulators are suddenly going after four tech and social media giants simultaneously - Facebook, Amazon, Google, and Apple.These four companies are part of my FANGMAN index that also includes Microsoft, Nvidia, and Netflix. The index dove 4.3% today, the biggest percentage decline since the infamous 4.6% drop on December 24, 2018. In terms of dollars, $137 billion in market capitalization was wiped out. Over the past four trading days the FANGMAN index has dropped by 6.6%. I highlighted today's move in red (market cap data via YCharts[5]):The index has gone through some brain-twisting surges and plunges over the past two years. It peaked on August 31, 2018 (at $4.63 trillion), then plunged 29% by December 24 (to $3.29 trillion), then exploded 40% higher by April 29. But that day, at $4.61 trillion, it failed to take out the August high. And then the selling started. Since April 29, the FANGMAN index has dropped 14.0%, or by $645 billion in market cap, giving up 49% of the post-Christmas rally in just five weeks. I track these stocks because of their outsized weight in the overall stock market, and because they range from very overvalued to immensely overvalued, depending on the stock - and symptomatic for much of the stock market. But given the sell-off over the past few weeks, what happened since Friday in terms of regulatory pressure was quite a handful. On Friday, the Wall Street Journal[6] reported that, according to its sources, the Justice Department 'has been laying the groundwork' for an anti-trust investigation into Google, the largest advertising platform in the world. Reuters reported on Monday that Google still 'declined comment.' The WSJ summarized the problem: The rise of big tech has seen three corporate titans that didn't exist 30 years ago - Amazon, Google, and Facebook - suddenly amassing the power to sway large parts of the U.S. economy and society, from the stock market to political discourse, from personal shopping habits to how small businesses sell their wares. With their enormous size and dominance have come network advantages, data caches and economies of scale that can make it challenging for new rivals to succeed. Many firms that compete with those giants in one sector also depend on their platforms to reach customers, and they complain of being unfairly squeezed. Google has already been hit with three mega-fines by the European Union's antitrust regulators, totaling €8.2 billion in three years: In June 2017, Google was fined €2.42 billion for abusing its position as the top search engine by giving preferential treatment to its own comparison-shopping service. In July 2018, Google was fined €4.34 billion for pushing smartphone makers into using its Android operating system. And in March 2019, Google was fined €1.5 billion concerning its search advertising. Over the weekend, it was reported that the FTC would have jurisdiction over a potential antitrust probe into Amazon's practices. And on Monday, Reuters reported that 'Amazon declined comment on Monday.' It was reported that, according to sources, the FTC would also have jurisdiction over a potential antitrust probe into Facebook, which also owns Instagram and WhatsApp. The FTC has long been investigating Facebook for privacy violations. In 2012, it approved a final settlement[7] with Facebook, 'resolving charges that Facebook deceived consumers by telling them they could keep their information on Facebook private, and then repeatedly allowing it to be shared and made public.' This settlement included a consent decree that Facebook subsequently was alleged to have violated by sharing user data with Cambridge Analytica. In April, Facebook said that it expected to be fined between $3 billion and $5 billion for these violations. Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) and Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.), members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, lambasted it as a 'bargain for Facebook'[8] that doesn't go nearly far enough in holding the company accountable to its users and forcing changes. 'Even a fine in the billions is imply a write-down for the company, and large penalties have done little to deter large tech firms,' they wrote in the letter. 'Fines alone are insufficient. Far-reaching reforms must finally hold Facebook accountable to consumers. We're deeply concerned that one-time penalties of any size every few years are woefully in adequate to effectively restrain Facebook.' They proposed a slew of reforms, including that 'personal responsibility must be recognized from the top of the corporate board down to the product development teams.' And they added, 'It is also time for the FTC to learn from a history of broken and under-enforced consent orders.' And it was reported over the weekend, again according to sources, that the Justice Department would have jurisdiction of a potential antitrust probe into Apple, which is already entangled in an investigation by EU regulators, following a complaint by Spotify that it abuses its power over app downloads. That puts the four companies simultaneously under the US regulatory microscope. And clearly, officials have been fanning out to let the media know. On Monday, Reuters[9] reported that 'people briefed on the matter say neither the Justice Department nor the FTC have contacted Google or Amazon about any probes, and that company executives are unaware of what issues regulators are reviewing.' So they got their info from the media. Divvying up jurisdiction was the first essential step. The rest might take years. Sources told Reuters on Monday that the government 'is gearing up to investigate whether Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google misuse their massive market power setting up what could be an unprecedented, wide-ranging probe of some of the world's largest companies.' Congress appears to be on board, according to Reuters: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham, a Republican, told Reuters that the business model of companies like Google and Facebook needs to be scrutinized. 'It's got so much power, and so unregulated,' he said. Another Republican, Senator Marsha Blackburn, said the panel would do what she called a 'deeper dive' into big tech companies. Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal, who said on Monday that U.S. enforcers have to do more than wring their hands about the companies' clout, also weighed in. 'Their predatory power grabs demand strict ...iff investigation ...titrust action,' the Connecticut senator wrote on Twitter. So let's see how that will turn out — if the outcome will effectively change business practices, or if any fines will just raise the cost of doing business, costs that can be written off as 'one-time charges' that analysts and the financial media eagerly exclude from earnings reports and hastily send into oblivion where they don't matter. But for now, the FANGMAN index shows that there is a price to pay.   https://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2019/06/fangman-stocks-crushed-by-potential-unprecedented-wide-ranging-probe-into-google-apple-facebook-amazon.html?utm_source=feedburner..._medium=feed..._campaign=Feed:+NakedCapitalism+%28naked+capitalism%29# ;This entry was posted in Banana republic[10], Economic fundamentals[11], Free markets and their discontents[12], Guest Post[13], Market inefficiencies[14], Politics[15], Regulations and regulators[16], Technology and innovation[17] on June 4, 2019[18] by Yves Smith[19]. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SNB-1SF1-JBVM-Y0XV-00000-00Fangs and claws2018-06-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 37Fangs and clawsAlistair Osborne

Fangs for nothing. That was the general sentiment towards regulators and politicians over their handling of the big four tech platforms: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google, the so-called "Fangs". How come they pay so little tax and escape the regulatory burdens of established rivals? Dame Carolyn McCall, the ITV boss, is hardly alone in finding it "quite odd" that Facebook can pay only £5.1 million UK corporation tax despite having £842 million in sales over here. Why, too, should the "publishers" Facebook and Google be allowed to self-regulate? "My biggest issue is how they are going to regulate www.online.No one knows how they are going to do that".

She called them "exponential" businesses. As Matthew Taylor, boss of the Royal Society for encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce, put it: "The data effect is reinforcing the network effect". He said Big Tech (the fifth "Faang" is Apple) had "unparalleled power in the history of capitalism" and suggested regulators break up Amazon.

How likely is that any time soon? Not remotely, according to the mood at the summit. One fear is that regulators and politicians don't understand Big Tech, not even culture secretary Matt Hancock, who says he does. Reining them in may take a consumer backlash, with users clawing back their data. The Facebook/Cambridge Analytica scandal shows why.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S04-FKW1-JCHV-V1YW-00000-00FANGS Bitten: Tech on the Skids as Regulators Circle Key Growth Sector2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisFANGS Bitten: Tech on the Skids as Regulators Circle Key Growth SectorMartin Baccardax

FANG stocks are on the skids again Wednesday as the rising star sector drags global markets lower following the Facebook data scandal and a re-think on self-driving cars following two fatal crashes in as many weeks.

U.S. technology stocks extended declines in pre-market trading Wednesday as investors continue to fret over the prospect of tighter regulation following Facebook Inc.'s data scandal and two fatal accidents linked to self-driving cars that have shaken faith in the market's star sector.

The NYSE FANG+ Index, which tracks the moves of ten of the biggest and most active tech stocks in the world, slumped 5.63% Tuesday to a six week low of 2441.50 points, taking $180 billion in market cap along with it and taking the benchmark of big tech stocks into correction territory from its March 12 peak. The broader S&P 500 Information Technology index was also sharply lower, falling 3.47% yesterday to wipe out all of its gains for the year.

The so-called index fell 5.6% yesterday (and it now more than 10% below peak) due to a combination of data leak scandal, risk of new regulation and considering restricting Chinese investments in/acquisitions of US tech companies

— Danske Bank Research (@Danske_Research)

Many of the stocks in the equal-weight index were also moving lower in pre-market trading again today, with Facebook marked 0.81% to the downside, Netflix Inc. marked 0.66% lower and Alibaba Holdings trading 0.34% to the downside. Telsa Inc. , however, was the standout decline, falling 1.28% to indicate an opening bell price of $275.50, the lowest in nearly a year.

Telsa is suffering following news that a fatal crash of one of its Model X vehicles in California last week has prompted an investigation from the U.S. National Transportation Board. Further pressure came from Moody's Investors Service, which lowered its credit rating on the clean energy carmaker deeper into junk status and warned that it faces "liquidity pressures due to its large negative cash flow and the pending maturities of convertible bonds."

Chipmaker Nvidia Corp. , which fell 7.76% yesterday after it said it suspended tests on self-driving cars following the death of a pedestrian in Arizona last week, was marked 0.46% to the downside at $224.50 each in pre-market trading.

Facebook shares were also slipping, falling 1.13% to indicate an opening bell price of $150.50 each, the lowest in 10 months and a move that would take the stock 21 lower from its early February peak. Apple Inc. was marked 0.74% lower at $167.10.

Twitter Inc.shares, which slumped 12% yesterday after a note from Citron Research warned that the social media group's business model of selling user data could trigger a sharper regulatory response than its rivals, was marked 0.89% lower at $27.82 each.

The Stoxx Europe 600 Technology index, the sector benchmark, was marked 2.73% lower at 423.34 points, taking the year-to-date decline to 3.56%, with Tesla Inc. supplier Infineon AG falling 4.6% , chipmaker AMS AG tumbling 7.8% and STMicroelectronics NV declining 4.73%.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WN4-PVP1-JCBB-K2DT-00000-00FANG Stocks Amazon, Alphabet To Report Amid Probe: Investing Action Plan2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisINVESTING ACTION PLANFANG Stocks Amazon, Alphabet To Report Amid Probe: Investing Action PlanJASON MA

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/Stock-amazon-21-shutter.jpg

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. FANG stocks will have another big day as Amazon and Google-parent Alphabet report, after the Justice Department announced a sweeping probe into anti-competitive practices among big tech companies. Chip giant Intel also issues earnings amid buzz that it's near a deal with Apple. Starbucks reports too.

Earnings From FANG Stocks

E-commerce leader Amazon will report late, and Wall Street expects EPS to rise 4% to $5.29, the slowest growth in seven quarters, as revenue grows 18% to $62.57 billion. The results come a week after Amazon had its fourth Prime Day shopping event, which saw a record 175 million items sold and more people signing up for memberships. Alphabet reports late as well, and analysts see EPS of $11.50, down 2%, with revenue climbing 18% to $30.9 billion.

But the focus during the conference calls will be on the Justice Department investigation. Earnings from the FANG stocks also come a week after executives from Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple were grilled on Capitol Hill during an antitrust hearing. Meanwhile, European Union regulators are also getting more aggressive with big U.S. tech companies.

Shares of Amazon closed up 0.3% at 2000.81 on the , and Alphabet slipped 0.7% to 1139.73.

Intel Earnings

The chip giant reports late Thursday, and EPS is seen sliding 14% to 89 cents, with sales dropping 8% to $15.6 billion. As with the FANG stocks, attention will likely turn away from Intel earnings and toward news that Apple is near a deal to buy the modem chip business of Intel. Apple could pay $1 billion or more for Intel patents and staff, the  reported Monday. In April, Intel announced it would shutter its modem chip business just as a landmark Apple-Qualcomm patent-and-royalties settlement was unveiled, raising speculation of a possible Apple-Intel modem chip deal.

Intel stock rose 2.3% to 52.92 Wednesday.

Starbucks Earnings

The coffee giant reports fiscal Q3 results after the close, and Wall Street expects Q3 EPS to climb 16% to 72 cents, as revenue increases 6% to $6.685 billion. Same-store sales are expected to rise 4.2%, with comps up 4.5% in the Americas, 0.9% in the Europe-Middle East-Africa segment, and 3.6% in the China and Asia-Pacific region, according to Consensus Metrix

Starbucks stock has soared more than 40% so far this year, and since late May has climbed more than 20%. One of the reasons is that Arabica coffee futures have been falling since October and took another sharp dive in June. They have since recovered somewhat but started falling again this month.

Starbucks CFO Patrick Grismer also boasted at the Piper Jaffray Consumer Marketplace Conference last month that consumer research indicates that while the firm is strong across all demographics, it "enjoys even higher levels of preference" with millennials and Gen Z consumers.

Starbucks stock edged up 0.6% to 90.65 Wednesday, just 1% below its record high reached last week.

Other Earnings

Atlassian reports fiscal Q4 earnings late, and analysts estimate EPS of 16 cents, up 23%, with revenue rising 36% to $331 million. Increased hiring in R&D and investments in cloud computing may lower the collaboration software developer's operating margins.

Comcast reports early, and analysts estimate 15% EPS growth to 75 cents, with revenue up 25% to $27.185 billion. Results will include the recent acquisition of U.K.-based Sky.

Stryker is expected late and analysts see the medical device maker's EPS rising 10% to $1.93 as revenue grows 8% to $3.605 billion.

Columbia Sportswear posts earnings after the close, and EPS is seen collapsing 94% to a penny as revenue ticks up 5% to $507 million.

Deckers Outdoor reports fiscal Q1 results late, and analysts expect the Ugg and Teva footwear maker to report per-share losses widening to $1.15 from 98 cents a year ago, as revenue grows 3.6% to $260 million.

Mattel reports after the close, and Wall Street sees per-share losses narrowing to 35 cents from 56 cents a year ago, as revenue dips 2.4% to $967 million. The toy maker's report comes after rival Hasbro reported blowout earnings earlier this week.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8G-5N51-JCBB-K185-00000-00FANG Stocks, Apple In Regulatory Crosshairs, Creating 'Headline Risks'2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYFANG Stocks, Apple In Regulatory Crosshairs, Creating 'Headline Risks'PATRICK SEITZ

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/stock-Google-1-company.jpg

Government regulators and politicians have declared open season on internet giants and appear set to nab some hunting trophies. That's why three of the four FANG stocks — Amazon.com, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet — along with tech icon Apple have taken a beating lately as investors worry about government and court actions defanging their businesses.

On Wall Street, analysts say rumblings about antitrust investigations create "headline risks" for the FANGs and Apple, sometimes known as .

"The headlines are, once again, ugly for big U.S. tech," Macquarie Research analyst Benjamin Schachter said in a report to clients Tuesday. "This is clearly not going to let up anytime soon. Still, headline risks have been around for years, but, for various reasons, they are particularly acute now."

He added, "Heading into a U.S. presidential election year, we expect headline risks to increase. Notably, there seems to be bipartisan support for creating such headlines. Taking on big U.S. tech seems to be in vogue across the political spectrum. This will have legs in our view."

A bigger worry than investigations is the possibility of regulatory remedies, Schachter said. Those remedies could include breaking up companies, fines, data privacy constraints, and other actions, he said. But any enforcement actions could be years away, he said.

FANG Stocks: Breakup Risks Relatively Low?

Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said the risk of large-cap tech company breakups, however, is relatively low.

"We view the likelihood of 'nuclear options' such as forced breakups of Google, Facebook or Amazon, and/or exposing search or feed algorithms, as fairly low," he said in his note to clients. Sebastian sees "the likelihood of antitrust action short of breakup as moderate; and regulation around privacy and security as relatively high."

The historical emphasis on "consumer harm" in U.S. antitrust cases could provide refuge for Facebook and Google, he said. That's because their services are mostly free to consumers.

Raymond James analysts said in their note that the biggest impact from the antitrust investigations could be that they prevent the internet giants from doing significant acquisitions in the future.

Starting To Recover

The FANG stocks and Apple sold off sharply on Monday amid reports of U.S. antitrust investigations. On Tuesday, they started to recover. On the , Alphabet — the hardest hit on Monday — rose 1.5% to 1,054.49. Meanwhile, Amazon increased 2.2% to 1,729.56 and Facebook rose 2% to 167.50. Apple made the biggest charge, climbing 3.7% to 179.64.

The fourth of the FANG stocks, Netflix, hasn't been caught up in the regulatory and legal whirlwind. But Netflix has its own challenges, namely rising competition from Walt Disney and others.

On , news reports indicated that U.S. regulatory bodies were preparing to start investigations into possible anti-competitive activities by Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google. The Department of Justice will look into the business practices of Apple and Google, while the Federal Trade Commission will investigate Amazon and Facebook. The DOJ and FTC share responsibility for enforcing and coordinate on which companies they oversee.

Sensing an opportunity to score points with voters, politicians have jumped on the bandwagon, calling for restraints on big tech firms.

House Judiciary Committee Launches Antitrust Investigation

The U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee it has launched a bipartisan investigation into competition in digital markets. The investigation will include a series of hearings by the Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law.

"A small number of dominant, unregulated platforms have extraordinary power over commerce, communication, and information online," the panel said in a statement that did not name any companies. "There are concerns that these platforms have the incentive and ability to harm the competitive process."

Some politicians, such as Democratic presidential candidate U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, are calling for the breakup of big tech companies including Amazon, Facebook and Google.

The FANG stocks and Apple also face increased regulatory scrutiny in the European Union.

Plus, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that consumers can press ahead with a lawsuit that accuses Apple of using its market dominance to artificially inflate prices at its App Store.

Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter at for more stories on consumer technology, software and semiconductor companies.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XWP-5591-JCBB-K11D-00000-00FANG Stocks Face Regulatory Scrutiny In 2020 — But So What?2020-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYFANG Stocks Face Regulatory Scrutiny In 2020 — But So What?BRIAN DEAGON

https://www.investors.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/TECH1-fb-010320-AP.jpg

FANG stocks — Facebook, Amazon.com, Netflix, and Google owner Alphabet — had a good showing in 2019. The same is true when the group includes Apple and becomes FAANG, as all five stocks surged by double digits over the past year.

But a big theme from 2019 expected to intensify in 2020 remains regulatory scrutiny by Congress and various government agencies, especially for Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google. They continue to face allegations revolving around antitrust activities, monopolistic practices and privacy concerns. Some members of Congress even suggest breaking the companies up.

Expect to see FANG executives spending much of their time on Capitol Hill during the next 12 months, defending their business practices.

"Regulation on FANG will be the political football kicked around in the Beltway with a number of paths this situation may take, especially heading into a presidential election year," Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives told Investor's Business Daily.

Still, the companies faced regulatory scrutiny in the past and weathered the storm without long-term damage — as seen by the performance of their stocks. Google and Apple, for example, trade near record highs. Facebook stock has recovered from previous drops and recently hit an 18-month high. One of the highest-prices stocks out there, Amazon consolidated during the second half of 2019. Meanwhile, Netflix recovers from recent lows wrought by increased competition.

"The Beltway battle with big tech has created a lot of noise and grandstanding," Ives said. "But unless the laws change there will be more headline risk rather than true business model risk."

FANG Stocks And Periodic Multibillion-Dollar Fines

In early December, Piper Jaffray analyst Yung Kim initiated coverage on Facebook. He started it with a rating of overweight, the equivalent of a buy.

"We do not expect the flow of news related to government inquiry and investigation into the company's business practices, data privacy, election tampering, etc., will subside any time soon," Kim wrote in a note to clients. "While this does pose a risk to Facebook shares, we believe most investors have become comfortable with the fact that this is an ongoing issue with risk of periodic multibillion-dollar fines."

To be sure, the road ahead will get bumpy for FANG stocks as investigations persist. In July, the U.S. Department of Justice announced a big  into Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon. It wants to determine if the tech giants are engaging in monopolistic anti-competitive activities.

In September, attorneys general for 50 U.S. states announced an antitrust investigation of Google. This embarks on a wide-ranging review of a tech giant that both Democrats and Republicans say threatens competition and consumers. The FTC also reportedly is considering a preliminary injunction against Facebook over antitrust concerns related to how its products interact.

Further, the European Union has also imposed or threatened fines and regulations against Facebook, Amazon and Google. These also revolve around privacy and antitrust matters.

"Regulatory risks exist but we don't see it as a game changer," said Wedbush's Ives. "We think FANG stocks will move 15%-to-20% higher over the next 6-to-9 months."

Big Companies, High Pressure

The FANG acronym was coined in 2013 by CNBC's "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer to collectively refer to Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google. Apple was added to the list in 2017, expanding the name to FAANG, though FANG remains the more commonly used search term.

The pressure put on the five companies is easy to understand, due to their influence and gargantuan size.

Facebook dominates social networking with more than 2 billion users. Amazon rules the e-commerce jungle as well as the market for cloud-computing services. Netflix is the leader in subscription video on demand, though competition is intensifying.

Alphabet is at the forefront of internet search and also plays an influential role in smartphones with its Google Android platform. In addition, Alphabet's YouTube dominates its field, with billions of hours of user video.

Apple has retained its loyal following for decades. That started with its computer users and strengthened after it virtually created the smartphone market.

Fallout Of Cambridge Analytica

As an example of FANG stock resilience, take a look at Facebook. It was in 2018 that revelations surfaced about the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica and how it improperly gained personal details on . The investigations expanded to include a host of additional privacy mishaps.

In July, Facebook agreed to and abide by sweeping new restrictions imposed by the Federal Trade Commission. The fine was the result of allegations Facebook deceived users about its handling of their personal information. The three FTC commissioners who in a 3-2 decision called the record-breaking fine a "historic victory" for American consumers.

But Wall Street shrugged as Facebook stock climbed 1% that day. And those who bought and held Facebook reaped a 56% gain during 2019.

A similar picture unfolds for any or all of the other four in the group. Apple stock soared 86% in 2019. Alphabet jumped 28%, while Netflix climbed 21% and Amazon added 23%.

FANG Stocks: Long In The Tooth?

Yet Dan Morgan, senior portfolio manager at Synovus Trust, thinks portfolio managers see FANG stocks as getting long in the tooth. The buy-and-hold strategy of FANG stocks is likely to keep working in 2020. But there are plenty of other attractive issues to buy and watch, he says.

"If you really wanted to make big money you just threw it at the FANG stocks and did well," Morgan told IBD. But the idea of just buying FANG stocks and ignoring the rest of the tech sector may not work as well in 2020, he adds.

"There's more to tech than just the FANG stocks," Morgan said. "Portfolio managers are becoming more discerning in terms of where to put their money. They're not just blindly buying the top five or six stocks."

Stocks that Morgan likes include AMD, up 155% in 2018, and Lam Research, which has more than doubled this year. Another is Microsoft, up 57%. He owns Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and business software maker Salesforce.com, which is up 20%.

For Wedbush's Ives, other technology stocks that he views optimistically include Microsoft, as a core play in cloud computing, CyberArk, in the cybersecurity market, and AMD in the chip sector.

Please follow Brian Deagon on Twitter at for more on tech stocks, analysis and financial markets.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S0B-XX61-DXXV-30NB-00000-00FANG stocks lose some bite;Tech giants have stumbled. Is it profit-taking by investors, or a sign of larger issues?2018-03-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBusiness DeskPart CPg. 1FANG stocks lose some biteTech giants have stumbled. Is it profit-taking by investors, or a sign of larger issues?James F. Peltz

It has become a lot less easy to make money in tech stocks.

A confluence of negative news has rocked the shares of the nation's leading technology companies in recent days, though many of them bounced back Thursday. Developments at companies such as Amazon and Tesla have prompted investors to take a hard, fresh look at the firms' growth prospects and the stocks' lofty prices.

Facebook Inc.was hit with a data-privacy scandal. Amazon.com Inc.came under attack again by President Trump over its sales taxes and U.S. Postal Service contract. Concern mounted about Tesla Inc.'s cash needs. The self-driving vehicle industry was roiled by a pedestrian fatality in Arizona caused by an autonomous Uber vehicle.

Because the tech giants' stocks -- and the stocks' enormous price gains in the last two years -- have attracted an increasingly larger following, their abrupt declines helped bring down the overall stock market in March.

For instance, the NYSE FANG+ index plunged nearly 8% this week before finishing nearly unchanged Thursday. The index tracks the so-called FANG stocks -- Facebook, Amazon, Netflix Inc.and Google parent Alphabet Inc. -- and six others, including Tesla and Twitter Inc.

The broader, tech-heavy Nasdaq composite index, which soared 28% last year and gained an additional 5.4% in the first two months of this year, fell 2.9% in March, its worst monthly showing since January 2016.

"The gains were easy the last few years" with the big tech shares, said Jason Ware, chief investment officer at Albion Financial Group. "Investors haven't been challenged much with these stocks. Now, there's been news that questions their assumptions.

"Investors are now saying, 'Maybe the stock isn't worth as much as we thought,' " he said.

But as Wall Street heads into a three-day break -- the market is closed for Good Friday -- the question is whether investors used the bad news simply to take some of their big profits or whether the developments point to trends that could curb the companies' longer-term business prospects, thus making current stock prices overvalued.

Consider: Even after tech's dreary week, Amazon is still up 66% over the last 12 months, compared with a 12% gain in the benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 index. Netflix has doubled in price and Twitter has surged 93% in the period.

The gains mainly reflect investors' expectations that the firms enjoy dominance in their various spheres and will continue their heady growth in the years to come.

With gains like those, the negative news gave many investors an apt reason to cash out. And some of those investors were momentum players with little interest in the companies' long-term outlooks, Ware said.

"These folks are not fundamentally rooted in their analysis," Ware said. "They're just renting the stock when there's momentum. And when that momentum starts to turn, these folks will flee and take their profits."

For those investors looking at the tech giants for the long term, "one of the questions we're getting is whether the recent declines in these stocks is indicative of something more sinister in the market," said Adam Phillips, director of portfolio strategy at EP Wealth Advisors in Torrance.

"We don't subscribe to that" thinking and, in fact, see the stocks' recent pullback as "making them more attractive," Phillips said.

One example for Phillips is Amazon. Many traders seemed to agree Thursday, as Amazon recovered from early losses -- and a 4.4% drop the prior day -- and finished with a gain of 1%.

Facebook jumped 4.4% on Thursday but was still down 17% from Feb. 1. Netflix and Alphabet both rose 3%. Apple Inc., which is one of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, rose nearly 1%.

"A lot of [the selling] was profit-taking but also an acknowledgment that these stocks, which have trended higher for quite some time, have come under a different scrutiny and are getting the wrong kind of attention," Phillips said.

Facebook provides a good example of the challenge longer-term investors now face.

Owing to the scandal involving Cambridge Analytica, which gathered data from about 50 million Facebook users without their permission, Facebook is being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission and could be the focus of regulatory reform by Congress.

One argument for investors is that "the Cambridge fiasco represents a seminal negative moment that will change the future business model and growth trajectory of Facebook," Daniel Ives, head of technology research at GBH Insights, said in a recent note to clients.

But Ives said "we ultimately believe Facebook will emerge from this crisis with minimal regulatory changes and limited financial damage to its user base and advertising kingdom," even if this represents "the darkest chapter for Facebook and [CEO Mark] Zuckerberg in its 14-year history."

--

james.peltz@latimes.com

PHOTO: AFTER YEARS of easy gains for tech investors, now they are facing challenges. Above, at the New York Stock Exchange after the closing bell Thursday. PHOTOGRAPHER:Bryan R. Smith AFP/Getty Images

Report; AT&T Shares Jump After Elliott Management Invests $3.2B; Boeing Aircraft 777X Fails Stress Test, Further Delays2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTSteven Mnuchin, Steven Rees, Mitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Doug CollinsNEWSFinancial090903cb.231Fannie & Freddie in Focus; Mnuchin: Talks with FHFA on Current Lines Expects an Agreement Soon; Mnuchin on U.S.-China Trade; Win For Bullied Boy, Homemade Shirt Now A University Best Seller; JPM Index Measures President Trump's Tweet Impact On Markets; I.G. Report On FBI Action During Russia Investigation Expected Out This Fall; House Dems Prepare To Formally Define Impeachment Probe; Congress Looking To Pass USMCA This Fall; Rep. Doug Collins (R-GA) is Interviewed About the I.G. Report; AT&T Shares Jump After Elliott Management Invests $3.2B; Boeing Aircraft 777X Fails Stress Test, Further DelaysMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Stuart Varney, Kristina Partsinevelos

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Dow Industrials up 1-1/2 percent at the close on Friday for the week. The S&P and the NASDAQ both up one and three quarters percent.

European Indices this morning, are mixed. We did get GDP numbers out for the U.K. The FT 100 is down 43 points, CAC Quarante is down 6, and the DAX Index is up 38. Britain's better-than-expected GDP report this morning, it was up 3/10 of a percent on the GDP. It did ease some recession fears. However, we know that the Eurozone is having a hard time generating any growth.

German exports were also up, though. Another good report here, up 7/10 of a percent in July, that was Germany. And Germany's DAX Index is up 37 points right now.

Japan, not as positive, second quarter GDP was up, but it was slower than expected, up 1.3 percent for the GDP in Japan, Nikkei Average up one half of one percent. In Asia overnight, markets were mixed, mostly higher, with the exception of Hong Kong, as you see, as protesters were on the street, once again, over the weekend.

Well, they are back, members of Congress returning to Washington today, facing a big to-do list, all of the hot-button issues on their plate, coming up this morning. Then, there is this, the Twitter effect, J.P. Morgan's new index measures the impact of President Trump's tweets. yes, we've got this Volfefe Index. We'll tell you about it.

And then, making it official, how the University of Tennessee is making a young fan's viral shirt into a reality. Good story there at the end of the day. We will tell you about it.

All those stories coming up, but first our top story this half an hour. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The Trump administration proposing a privatization of these mortgage finance giants, which could keep them at the center of the U.S. housing market for years to come.

Joining me right now to talk about that and a host of other topics is U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin.

Mr. Secretary, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks for being here.

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: Hi, Maria, it's good to be with you as well.

BARTIROMO: All right. So you -- the Treasury has submitted the housing reform plan to the president. Can you -- I have it here, 53 pages worth of it. Can you talk about the housing plan to, once again, privatize these companies, these government-sponsored entities, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and how that should play out from your standpoint, sir.

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, as you know, these have been in conservatorship for 11 years and we think now is the time to recapitalize them, make them stronger, make sure that taxpayers aren't at risk and eventually erase third party capital so that we restructure them and that in another housing downturn taxpayers are not at risk.

BARTIROMO: So -- so one of the issues here is you've got to get private capital, you've got to get competition in the marketplace, but you also have to get capital to come into this situation. So how are you going to do it?

Pull out some of the more important items from this housing reform plan that you think is going to solve -- that you think will, in fact, move the needle on that?

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, the first step is we are in the process of negotiating with the FHFA on our current lines and we expect in the near term we'll have an agreement where we will allow both Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to retain their earnings, which will be a significant increase in capital and a step in the right direction to us ultimately raising third party capital.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think you make a really important point because, you know, I was reading a couple of the comments on Twitter and on social media and, you know, people are saying, look, how soon are we going to get Fannie and Freddie out of conservatorship now that you had a pretty good win the other day, the ruling, the APA claim in the -- in the fifth circuit. And the fact that people feel that it was unconstitutional in the first place to force these companies to have all their profits go to the Treasury and tell them when and when they should and shouldn't pay dividends.

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, I'm not going to comment on the legal case for obvious reasons, but I would say what we're focused on is is housing reform. And as part of housing reform, we do want to make sure that there is real capital in front of the taxpayers. The other issue, and I look forward to testifying at the Senate tomorrow, will be looking for bipartisan legislation to get approval to have -- to put a full faith and credit on the securities. And we think that the government should be paid for that wrap and we think there should be significant private capital in front of it. So something similar to the FDIC model or the Ginnie Mae wrap.

BARTIROMO: Right. I mean, look, we've talked about this before. And in the past you've -- you've actually agreed with my assessment that for a time the Obama administration was just taking money from these companies and putting it wherever they wanted. I mean the investors get totally screwed, Fannie and Freddie, and now people are saying, look, the government looted Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. When are we going to be able to get our money back?

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, I'm not going to comment on the investors' situation, but I will comment on -- you're right, they've been in conservatorship for too long and we want to make sure they're not in conservatorship on a permanent basis. So our first choice is to work with Congress on a bipartisan basis. But if we can't do that, we're perfectly comfortable moving forward on the administrative side and making the changes we need to do.

BARTIROMO: All right, look, this is a big issue for investors, as you know. And you -- I know you don't want to touch certain things, but -- but what - - what can you tell us about the fact that this federal appeals court in New Orleans overturned the ruling, and that ruling that backed the government's right to take all of the mortgage giant's profits?

In addition to that, the judge has, Mr. Secretary, as you know, the judge has also concluded that the structure of Fannie and Freddie's regulator, that's the Federal Housing Finance Agency, is unconstitutional because of job protections for the agency's director.

What do you say?

MNUCHIN: Well, we've obviously been working with the Department of Justice on this case. We're reviewing the decision. And we're -- we're not going to let this stand in the way, one way or another, with housing reform. So, as I say, there is an investor issue here, which will continue to go through the legal process, but the most important issue is, regardless of that case, we will restructure Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac so that they have private capital in front of any taxpayer risks.

BARTIROMO: How long will this take? What's the timing on that? Do you believe you can actually get new capital into the situation and allowing these companies to return to the private sector?

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, I think we're -- we're going to work with Congress on the first part of this. I'd hope that if we're going to get congressional support, it will be in the next three to six months. And if we can't do that, we'll move on on the administrative front.

And as I said earlier, the first step of -- of capital will be, we expect in the very near term, to reach an agreement to allow for capital to be built up. So right now they each have three billion of capital and they have the Treasury lines and we're going to start with retaining earnings so that that's the first step in capital raise.

BARTIROMO: One -- one investor wants to know, given the -- the ruling that -- on net worth sweep that we now know was illegal, is the September sweep going to be halted? Are we going to see money go back to the investors?

MNUCHIN: Well, the money wouldn't go back to the investors. The money would stay in the companies. And then, obviously, the legal process will go forward.

And, obviously, the Treasury has very significant claims for the money that we've outlaid. But, you know, I expect, we're -- we're going to -- we're in the process of working with the FHFA and we're going to try to see if we can do it in September. If not, it will be very soon after that.

BARTIROMO: What -- what would be a realistic timeframe in your mind that Fannie and Freddie could -- could come out of conservatorship?

MNUCHIN: Maria, it just depends. We're going to do it as quickly as we can. As I said, part of it depends on how quickly we get Congress to act. But we're going to -- we're going to make sure that we lay out a plan to getting these entities out of conservatorship. That is our goal.

BARTIROMO: And tell -- and connect the dots for us for the audience. Why do you think that's going to help the housing market? What will that mean overall at the end of the day, given the fact that right now these companies control, what, 95 percent of mortgages, Mr. Secretary?

MNUCHIN: Well, it's these companies with FHA control a very, very big part of the market.

And let me just comment on, this is really housing reform. And we are also working with HUD on looking at reform of FHA. We want to make sure that if we fix Fannie and Freddie, we don't put the taxpayers at risk at FHA. So that -- that's also something we're looking very closely at and we're working with Secretary Carson on.

BARTIROMO: Do you believe the FHFA exceed its statutory authority as a conservator?

MNUCHIN: Maria, that's a nice try, but you know I'm not going to comment on that.

BARTIROMO: All right, let me -- let me switch gears, Secretary Mnuchin, because, obviously, this whole conversation of recession has -- has taken over. A lot of people worry that the jobs number on Friday showed a slowdown in the economy. Where are we on that? What can you tell us as we watch these numbers come in? And a lot of people are blaming the president's trade policy leading to uncertainty. And that is causing managers to sit on cash.

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, there's no question there's a considerable slowdown in the world economy, both in China and in Europe. But as you look at the U.S., we continue to be the bright spot of growth.

I just came from the G7 with the president a few weeks ago, and that's what everybody was talking about, the president's economic plan of tax cuts, regulatory relief and trade are really what's driving the U.S. economy.

I don't see, in any way, a U.S. recession. I think if you look at interest rates, I think what you see is both in terms of long term interest rates, which are at a historic low, which is good for the economy, I think you see that on a relative basis we're still high relative to the rest of the world on interest rates, and you also see the market's expectation of the Fed doing rate cuts. So I don't, in any way, think that the yield curve reflects a recession. And as far as we see, very healthy, robust growth for the balance of the year.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean I -- I know that the numbers are still showing growth. So the whole idea that we're going to be in a recession doesn't make a lot of sense to me either because you are seeing actual solid numbers in terms of growth.

But what can you say to investors and people out there who might be worried that the uncertainty around China, the uncertainty around this tariff situation is causing the economy to stall, even if it is the jewel of the world, and I get that. It is certainly the best story out there in the global economy.

MNUCHIN: Well, Maria, you know that the president is, you know, wants to deal with this very important issue of China trade. And we've been working on this for the last two and a half years. Since the first meeting we had with President Trump and President Xi, there was an agreement on both sides to rebalance the trading relationship so it was a fairer relationship. And Ambassador Lighthizer and I have been working very hard to get to that that result. And if we can get a good deal, which is our objective, we'll enter into a deal with China.

We have talks coming up on the vice minister level this month with them coming here and then with the vice premier coming here in the beginning of October. Our objective is to get a good deal. A deal that's good for American workers and American companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And you have been the front man, you and Bob Lighthizer, talking with the Chinese. So without giving anything away, because I know that you can't, do you think there's a willingness on that side to actually attack things, Secretary Mnuchin, that are the big ticket items?

I'm not talking about the theft of intellectual property and the forced transfer of technology. Isn't that the reason that they reneged back in April because they didn't want an enforcement mechanism in place that would have created consequences if they went back to their old ways of stealing.

MNUCHIN: Well, I think the talks broke down less about enforcement on -- and partially on other issues where there was significant pushback in China. I think the enforcement area, we at least have a conceptual -- an agreement on.

But, again, we have a document. We've made a lot of progress. They're coming here. I take that as a sign of good faith that they want to continue to negotiate. And we're prepared to negotiate. If we can get a good deal, a deal that's good for us, we'll sign it. If not, the president is perfectly fine with continuing the tariffs, which are raising significant amounts of money for the U.S. Treasury.

BARTIROMO: Is it fair to say it's impacted the Chinese economy, but it's also impacted the U.S. economy?

MNUCHIN: It's fair to say it's impacted the Chinese economy. We have not yet seen any impact on the U.S. economy. So I think, as you know, we've navigated this very carefully. There's no question that the RMB has depreciated significantly. That's paid for the majority of the tariffs.

I think there have been certain situations where there have been difficulties for companies and Ambassador Lighthizer has done a very good job managing the exception process on a case by case basis. So we have not seen an impact on the U.S. economy and we'll be very carefully managing that.

BARTIROMO: Can you really say that even though we are seeing growth slow down because of uncertainty around trade? Can you really say it hasn't impacted the economy here?

MNUCHIN: Yes, I can really say that. And when you say growth has slowed down, you know, let me just comment that these numbers have volatility on the upside and the downside. There's no question that our growth is significantly higher than the rested of the world. There's no question that to a certain extent global growth will have a moderate impact on U.S. growth. COLLINS: What we've got to do is actually get the folks in here and working on these big tech companies. The board, though, has weighed in on the Time Warner merger. We know that AT&T bought Time Warner for $85 billion. The board still says at this point, it's too soon to tell whether AT&T can create value with Time Warner.

And it's also recommended that a third party review AT&T to look for some added growth opportunities. And switching gears, though, we talked about a stock that's up about six percent. Boeing, we're seeing Boeing down this morning and a lot of it has to do with a test of the 777X. This is a long- haul wide body plane. It failed its stress test. The stress test is used to check for heavy loads. Supposedly according to the Seattle Times, the cargo door actually blew out during the stress test. So, this is just another hiccup for the company, as many of the 737s, all the 737s are grounded. This is the Max 8 and so the company is trying to push out another long-haul wide body plane and clearly not doing so well. Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Kristina. Thank you. Kristina Partsinevelos. Still ahead, we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Mitch Roschelle.

ROSCHELLE: We have some economic data coming out. We got Producer Price Index, CPI, and inflation, and also retail sales, and I'm looking at retail sales to see if the consumer is still strong because that's the thing that's driving our economy.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. That's key. Lee.

CARTER: I'm looking forward to the Democrat debates this week. Thursday night. We're going to have a big night. You know, right now, if this were 2015, Trump would have run away. So, is Biden going to be the candidate? Is Elizabeth Warren going to continue to have her lead? Who is the Democratic Party going to decide they want to be? I think it's going to be interesting to watch.

BARTIROMO: Are they going to try to take down Trump or take down each other on Thursday night?

CARTER: You know what?

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

CARTER: No, I think their whole thing has been about taking down Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: And I don't think it's a smart strategy because we don't know what they stand for. We know what they stand against.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. There you go.

CARTER: And being the party that stand against everything is not going to get us excited.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Dagen, what do you think?

MCDOWELL: They stand for reducing our quality of life and --in the United States because their climate change proposals, it's immoral.

BARTIROMO: Seven hours the other night on CNN. Have a great day, everybody. Let's get to "VARNEY & CO." Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: And I bet you didn't watch it all the way through.

urn:contentItem:60M9-K3D1-DYRR-94G2-00000-00Fans are stuck in the middle of Fortnite fight2020-08-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisMONEYPg. 4BFans are stuck in the middle of Fortnite fightMike Snider, USA TODAY

The Fortnite competition is going way beyond the game.

First, Epic Games, the publisher of the popular online video game, introduced a direct payment option for mobile players - sidestepping the Apple App store and Google Play store payment methods, which nets each of those tech giants a cut of the revenue.

Apple and Google, subsequently, pulled the mobile game from their stores. Epic Games' answer? Suits filed against both companies describing each one's app store as anti-competitive and monopolistic.

How the confrontation plays out has massive implications for how - and who - consumers pay for apps such as games and streaming entertainment. "This is a big deal," said Michael Pachter, an analyst with Wedbush Securities, in a note to investors. "Epic is challenging Apple's (and Google's) pricing within their stores and offering an alternative for users to get the same thing at a lower price."

What is the argument?

Founded in 1991, Epic Games is well-known as the publisher of games such as Unreal, Gears of War and Infinity Blade, as well as the Unreal Engine, which powers countless video games from Batman Arkham Asylum to Sea of Thieves.

Its free-to-play Fortnite, released in September 2017, has become a hit with 350 million players across multiple gaplatforms including video game consoles, PCs, and Android and iOS smartphones and tablets. The game generated an estimated $2.4 billion in revenue in 2018 and $1.8 billion in 2019, according to SuperData, a Nielsen company.

Fortnite is free to play, but you can buy in-game currency called V-Bucks which is used to purchase weapons, customized outfits and dances, or emotes, for their in-game personas. When players on Apple and Android devices spend, Apple and Google get a 30% cut of those sales.

Epic Games CEO Tim Sweeney has argued that the online marketplaces that sell games - Apple's App Store, the Google Play store and Valve's PC game store Steam - take an unfair cut from game sales and in-game transactions.

Its new mobile payment system for Fortnite players on Android and iOS devices gives players a discount compared with buying through the Apple and Google apps. As of Thursday, players could choose to buy 1,000 V-Bucks directly from Epic Games for $7.99 - the same price as on PCs or home video game consoles. Through Apple's App Store and Google Play, the same purchase costs $9.99.

It's not Epic's first move against what it considers higher-than-suitable charges. In December 2018, Epic opened its own online PC game download store, charging game makers 12% for sales, to compete with Steam, which also charges a 30% cut on sales.

"It's about economic efficiency when you have these stores sucking out a huge fraction of the profits from games," Sweeney told The Verge in April 2019. "Valve, Apple, and Google make more profit through their storefront fees than the devs make off their own games."

Are app stores anti-competitive?

Not inherently. App stores serve as one-stop shopping for consumers for all kinds of applications including games. And the device you use allows you to make a choice on which marketplace to support.

Within the app stores, companies such as Apple and Google curate content and help connect game makers with consumers. "There is value to that," Pachter says. "Epic doesn't dispute the value, but thinks it's closer to 12% than to 30%."

Dan Niles, founding partner of AlphaOne Capital Partners, told CNBC that Apple deserves payment for access to its App Store. "I mean, I have a lot of issues with Apple, but the charges they put on the App Store is not one of them," he said. "I mean, at the end of the day, Epic Games chose to be on the platform; those were the terms. If they didn't want to do it, they didn't have to, and they get a lot of benefit from being able to access Apple's 1.5 billion devices globally."

Does this mean higher or lower prices?

That depends. If you are currently a Fortnite player on Android or iOS through Epic's payment method, you are getting lower prices with that 20% discount. And Epic's prices on consoles and PCs apparently seem reasonable to the millions who pay for V-Bucks on those platforms.

Developers such as Epic, the company argues in its suit against Apple, are forced to charge higher prices "in order to pay Apple's app tax."

Breaking Apple's hold on distribution - and giving developers access to iPhones directly - would lead to to lower prices, says Sandeep Vaheesan, legal director of Open Markets Institute. Tying arrangements, such as software for devices, require consumers to pay for a product that could be priced higher simply because the party - in this case, Apple - has certain power and leverage in the market, he says.

"When firms such as Apple dominate a market, they decide who participates and on what terms," he said in a statement. "Epic's lawsuit is an important move against Apple's monopoly in the sale of iPhone apps. The federal judiciary must enforce existing antitrust prohibitions, including the categorical ban on tying by firms with power, and open the app market for iPhone owners and app developers."

But an open market could lead to consumers paying another way - with less secure and less reliable apps - argues tech consultant and business adviser Shelly Palmer in a blog post. Apple and Google created online malls and they "rent space to 3rd parties. The price is 30% of your sales. For that 'fee,' you are given access to millions of potential customers. There is no version of a mobile Fortnite without the app stores," he said. "The app store guidelines basically ensure a level of quality control for end users."

Alex Kantrowitz, founder of the newsletter Big Technology, told CNBC that Apple should back down, and lower Epic's fee. "Rent collecting is bad for its business long term. So you have to decide as a business, do you want to make your money milking your asset or do you want to make your money innovating into the future?"

In the end, whether prices go up or down will depend on how this standoff is resolved. Still, Pachter is doubtful that developers will reduce prices.

What happens when Fortnite gets an update later this month and current players cannot get the new content? Will their anger be directed at Apple and Google or Epic? And then, what will the response be?

When will this be resolved?

If the disputes play out in the courts, they could take a long time. The parties could come to a settlement.

And the threat of congressional regulation on big tech could be enough for Apple to submit.

Apple, in the past, has made deals. It reduced how its cut from 30% to 15% after Spotify subscribers' first year. Spotify filed an antitrust complaint against Apple in the European Union last year, charging the "Apple tax" and other measures hamper its growth.

During the April-June quarter, Apple reported revenue from Services, which includes the App Store, Apple Music, iTunes movie rentals and iCloud online storage, of $13.1 billion, up from $11.4 billion a year ago.

Epic, which is private, is braced for battle. Earlier this month, it got $1.78 billion in investments, including $250 million from Sony to acquire a minority interest in Epic, boosting the company's valuation to $17.3 billion.

The influx, Sweeney said in an announcement, "accelerates Epic's efforts to build a new kind of digital ecosystem using real-time 3D technology, services that connect hundreds of millions of people, and a digital storefront that offers a fair business model."

urn:contentItem:54W6-T9R1-JCW9-X2K4-00000-00FAQ: Facebook's IPO2012-02-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. A07FAQ: Facebook's IPO

The most anticipated IPO since Googleis one step closer to happening. Facebookfiled documents with the government late Wednesday laying out plans for its initial public stock offering. Here are some frequently asked questions and answers about the IPO: How much will Facebookstock cost?



The company hasn't said yet. It also hasn't said how many shares there will be. It will update its filings several times before the stock offering, which could be in May or June.

How much will it raise in the IPO?

The filing says up to $5 billion, which would make it the largest Internet IPO. But the figure could grow even larger.

What will it use the money for?

Facebookdoesn't have any specific plans. Its main reason for the IPO was to give its employees and investors a way to cash out their stock.

Will it pay a dividend?

It says it doesn't plan one any time soon. But many newly public tech companies don't have dividends.

How does it make money?

It sells advertisements to companies that want to reach Facebook's 845 million users. Ads made up 85 percent of revenue last year. Facebookalso gets a cut of sales that "Farmville" maker Zynga and other companies make through its site.

Is it profitable?

Yes, it earned $1 billion last year, up 65 percent from $606 million in 2010.

What are some of the risks of owning Facebook?

More users are going to Facebookon phones and other mobile devices, where it doesn't show ads. Facebooksays it may add sponsored stories in its mobile news feeds to earn revenue, but it isn't sure if it will be successful in making money off mobile.

Facebookis looking to expand overseas, but access to it is restricted in China, the world's most populous country.

The company has faced a series of controversies over the privacy of users' data. Last year, it settled with the Federal Trade Commission on privacy issues.

Facebookfaces competition from Google, Microsoft and Twitter.

How have other big tech IPOs done recently?

Many of those that went public last year rose on their first day of trading, but have sunk since then. LinkedIn priced its stock at $45 and closed at $94.25 on May 19, its first trading day. It's now $76.98. Google's IPO has been more lucrative: It sold its stock initially at $85 in August 2004 and rose to $100.34 the first day. It's now $585.11.

Ticker: FB 2011 revenue: $3.71 billion Revenue from U.S.: 56 percent Revenue from abroad: 44 percent 2011 rev. growth: 88 percent Employees: 3,200 Cash holdings: $3.9 billion Long-term debt: none

FAQ: Facebook's IPO

Facebookdoesn't have any specific plans. Its main reason for the IPO was to give its employees and investors a way to cash out their stock.

Will it pay a dividend?

It says it doesn't plan one any time soon. But many newly public tech companies don't have dividends.

How does it make money?

It sells advertisements to companies that want to reach Facebook's 845 million users. Ads made up 85 percent of revenue last year. Facebookalso gets a cut of sales that "Farmville" maker Zynga and other companies make through its site.

Is it profitable?

Yes, it earned $1 billion last year, up 65 percent from $606 million in 2010.

What are some of the risks of owning Facebook?

More users are going to Facebookon phones and other mobile devices, where it doesn't show ads. Facebooksays it may add sponsored stories in its mobile news feeds to earn revenue, but it isn't sure if it will be successful in making money off mobile.

Facebookis looking to expand overseas, but access to it is restricted in China, the world's most populous country.

The company has faced a series of controversies over the privacy of users' data. Last year, it settled with the Federal Trade Commission on privacy issues.

Facebookfaces competition from Google, Microsoft and Twitter.

How have other big tech IPOs done recently?

Many of those that went public last year rose on their first day of trading, but have sunk since then. LinkedIn priced its stock at $45 and closed at $94.25 on May 19, its first trading day. It's now $76.98. Google's IPO has been more lucrative: It sold its stock initially at $85 in August 2004 and rose to $100.34 the first day. It's now $585.11.

Ticker: FB 2011 revenue: $3.71 billion Revenue from U.S.: 56 percent Revenue from abroad: 44 percent 2011 rev. growth: 88 percent Employees: 3,200 Cash holdings: $3.9 billion Long-term debt: none

Source: regulatory filings Stan Choe, J.Paschke Â· AP

The most anticipated IPO since Googleis one step closer to happening. Facebookfiled documents with the government late Wednesday laying out plans for its initial public stock offering. Here are some frequently asked questions and answers about the IPO: How much will Facebookstock cost?



The company hasn't said yet. It also hasn't said how many shares there will be. It will update its filings several times before the stock offering, which could be in May or June.

How much will it raise in the IPO?

The filing says up to $5 billion, which would make it the largest Internet IPO. But the figure could grow even larger.

What will it use the money for?

Facebookdoesn't have any specific plans. Its main reason for the IPO was to give its employees and investors a way to cash out their stock.

Will it pay a dividend?

It says it doesn't plan one any time soon. But many newly public tech companies don't have dividends.

How does it make money?

Facebookis looking to expand overseas, but access to it is restricted in China, the world's most populous country.

The company has faced a series of controversies over the privacy of users' data. Last year, it settled with the Federal Trade Commission on privacy issues.

Facebookfaces competition from Google, Microsoft and Twitter.

It's now $76.98. Google's IPO has been more lucrative: It sold its stock initially at $85 in August 2004 and rose to $100.34 the first day. It's now $585.11.
