urn:contentItem:5SHG-C1N1-JBHT-D189-00000-00Fashion Designer Found Dead in Apparent Suicide; Bill Clinton Under Fire; Primary Election Day; Interview With Wyoming Senator John Barrasso2018-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisFashion Designer Found Dead in Apparent Suicide; Bill Clinton Under Fire; Primary Election Day; Interview With Wyoming Senator John BarrassoLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: This is as big as it gets before the big midterm Election Day.

The race on in eight states holding crucial primaries today, among them, California and New Jersey, which could hold the key to whether Democrats regain the House of Representatives this November.

In California alone, more than $108 million has reportedly been spent on a very crowded congressional field of races, to say nothing of the gubernatorial battle.

The outcome could have a huge impact on everything from the economy, to trade, to taxes, and possibly slam the brakes on the president's agenda. Talk about a lot at stake.

Welcome. I'm Neil Cavuto, and this is "Your World."

We're all over it with FOX Business Network's Deirdre Bolton on the seats that Democrats are trying to flip. There are quite a few. Hillary Vaughn in Orange County, California, on how some win-or-take-all primaries could leave some Democrats flipping out. And FOX Business Network's Connell McShane in Iowa on if the president's trade policies could be a big flop for Republicans.

We begin with Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Neil.

Well, National Democrats tell me this California primary is make or break. And voting is under way right now in Huntington Beach, California, one of the districts Democrats poured millions of dollars into. They have been counting on a blue wave hitting California to add to their tally of seats they want to flip across the country to secure the House majority in November.

But national Democrats tell me they're worried they could be left off the ballot entirely because too many of them are running. So, the DCCC has had to dump millions in the races, ask candidates to get out of the race.

But still, they're worried that it won't be enough. They're targeting 10 seats in the race, four right here in Orange County, two open seats from Republican representatives retiring, Darrell Issa and Ed Royce.

But they're also targeting two seats that Republican incumbents are trying to hold on to, Congressman Rohrabacher and Mimi Walters.

Here's why, because these four districts voted for Hillary Clinton in 2016. So, Democrats saw an opening they want to use for their advantage in 2018.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DANA ROHRABACHER (R), CALIFORNIA: I'm up against two millionaires, and we know that there's billionaires who are financing most of what the Democratic Party does. So the public is going to wake up to that. And it's not in their -- the interests of hardworking people to support some political clique that is trying to basically control the state and control their lives.

I'm very confident and the Republican Party is about ready to surge back in California, as compared to this blue wave that we're being told is coming.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Here in Huntington Beach, Rohrabacher is not only fending off Democrats, but also a fellow Republican in this primary.

Republican Scott Baugh is close friends with Rohrabacher, but he's also fighting for his seat. He says it's good for Republicans, because if they are the two that face off in November, that would leave Democrats off the ballot entirely.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: You're challenging Rohrabacher, a fellow Republican. So, what I want to know is, how do you think that actually helps Republicans on primary night today?

SCOTT BAUGH (R), CALIFORNIA CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: Well, are you kidding me?

If the Republicans have two in the playoffs, two in the general election, it means that this seat is removed from the Democrat calculation altogether. They can't win the seat, it's impossible, because they don't have a candidate in the general elections.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: A Democratic lockout could be a huge nightmare for Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who has said the pathway to victory for them runs through California right here.

But I talked to Democratic candidates that they have hand-picked and they're still not ready to vocalize their support for a potential Speaker Pelosi run if the Democrats were successful to win the majority in November -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, Hillary Vaughn, thank you very, very much.

To put California and some of these other states in perspective, California and New Jersey alone have 12 Republican seats now held that could easily flip. That is about half the number that Democrats would need alone to regain control of the House of Representatives.

That's how much is at stake in just two prominent states. But that's not all that is up for grabs.

FOX Business Network's Deirdre Bolton keeping track of some of the tossup races and issues that could have a huge impact.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Neil, there's a lot, so California is so important.

And, I mean, experts are really saying these primaries are going to potentially be make-or-break contests for both parties. So here's the short list, the ones that we're really focused on in the Golden State.

So, the 10th Congressional District, the incumbent there, Republican Jeff Denham, that is his photo there. Now, in the 2016 presidential election, Secretary Clinton beat President Trump by three percentage points in that district.

So, another that we're following, the 25th Congressional District. The incumbent there, Republican Steve Knight. And if you go back to the presidential election, you had a 7 percentage point gain by the Democrats, and that was of course Hillary Clinton vs. President Trump.

In California's 48th Congressional District, the incumbent there, Republican Dana Rohrabacher, there is his photo there. And if you go back to the presidential election, it's only a 2 percentage point lead that Hillary Clinton had over President Trump.

Immigration, that is one of the most volatile issues for all of these races. That may motivate voters to show up. California is home to more immigrants, legal, undocumented, than any other state in the U.S. It's a huge issue there.

Also, of those three key races that we highlighted, they are all ones that have sanctuary city status. So, people are very clear either on one side or the other particularly about illegal immigration.

The other big issue that may motivate California voters is the threat of trade wars. So, California grows tons of almonds, beans, milk, pork, some of which is exported. California as a whole produces and sells more than $15 billion worth of agricultural products.

Now, in that 10th Congressional District, all by itself, more than $2.5 billion of goods are sold there. So, one of our 50 states, of course California. But, as a stand-alone country, like this trivia point, it would be the world's sixth largest economy.

Neil, you mentioned those three seats in New Jersey. And, of course, one of the things that the Republicans are going to be fighting against are the Trump administration's tax plans, which hurt a lot of real estate owners and real estate investors in New Jersey.

CAVUTO: Right.

BOLTON: There's a lot of people pretty bitter about that. And some calls I made, they said, listen, if you're independent, if you're on the line, that actually may help Democrats, if for no other reason than revenge of what people feel in their own pockets.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Yes, their deductions were dramatically limited.

BOLTON: Yes.

CAVUTO: All right, Deirdre, thank you very, very much.

In the meantime, will the economy trump fears of a trade war in today's primaries?

Let's get the read from Connell McShane, who has been talking to farmers out in Iowa, USA Today's congressional reporter Eliza Collins, and The Wall Street Journal's Shelby Holliday.

Connell, out there in farmland, of course, they're surprised. Big backers of Donald Trump in general, but concerned about a trade war that could have the Chinese not buying a lot of the stuff they produce, right?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes.

Neil, what is interesting on this very program yesterday, as you remember, Neil, we had a farmer named Ron Heck on the show from here in Iowa. And he was talking about some of the concerns.

But what I will say after spending a couple days out here on the ground -- and this is just anecdotal, speaking to Heck and some others this morning out at a Dubuque diner about this very subject -- is just because you assume that one thing is true, in other words, a trade war policy or a protectionist policy from the White House is going to hurt somebody, the president, Republicans, politically, doesn't necessarily mean it's going to play out that way.

Again, it's just anecdotal. But in speaking to people, the president, among his supporters, Neil, he has built up a lot of equity with tax cuts, with deregulatory policies, where that support seems to still be solid from the people who supported him in the past. And they're cutting him some slack and willing to see how this trade debate and trade discussion will play out over a matter of time.

I have been a little bit surprised by it.

CAVUTO: And as you reported earlier as well, the Chinese offered a -- maybe a first opening salvo here to buy $70 billion of U.S. agricultural- related products here. So, that could ease a lot of this angst if it turns out to be a concession on the Chinese part. There's been no follow-up. We will see.

You know, Eliza, when you look at what's going on here, the view had been not too long ago that we face a blue wave here, that Democrats were certainly going to gain a lot of seats, enough to tip the balance of power in the either House and/or Senate, less likely the Senate, still possibly the House.

And then along came an improving economy, along came a startlingly good jobs report, and now they're not so sure. What is the latest read?

ELIZA COLLINS, USA TODAY: Exactly.

The economy's improvement and the steady, strong economy has really helped Republicans. They feel good about their tax cuts, although they have not been -- like we have analyzed advertisements. That's not been the number one issue they have been talking about, which is a little bit interesting.

But it's certainly helping them. There is concern from Republicans here at the Capitol about these impending trade wars, so much concern, that they're actually talking about a bill right now that could basically give Congress the authority to vote up or down the president's proposed tariffs in the future based on national security.

We don't know if that has enough votes right now, but it's certainly being discussed. And something interesting is, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has not ruled it out of being added or at least voted on a separate piece of legislation.

So, he's not stopping it, which does say that Republicans here are concerned about the effects of a possible trade war.

CAVUTO: We should also mention, and she did, you know, Shelby, this idea that Republicans, Mitch McConnell are concerned enough about getting more stuff done, that they're going to be working through the August recess, or at least that's the plan.

What is the political fallout of that?

SHELBY HOLLIDAY, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Well, politically, some of these Republicans will not be at home in their districts.

That means less time on the campaign trail meeting voters, shaking hands. But, on the flip side, if they get a lot done and they accomplish things Republicans want to see them accomplish, it could be a good thing.

So, right now, kind of hard to say. I will say that it's impossible to know what will be top of mind for voters come November. The Trump presidency seems to change news cycles every hour, if not every day.

But if economy is top of mind -- I was looking through some Wall Street polls -- and most voters feel that the Republicans are in a better place to handle the economy, things like taxes, trade, the deficit.

However, if an issue like immigration or health care is top of mind for voters, that could hurt the GOP.

And I would add the trade -- the question about a trade war has thrown a huge wrench into this, because if there's a trade war and if most voters start to think that Democrats could handle the economy better, if they start to think Democrats would be better on trade, then you see this huge list of issues that most voters would feel Democrats are better on.

And that could really threaten Republicans come November in the midterms.

CAVUTO: All right, guys, I want to all very, very much.

Just a reminder here, the typical rule of thumb in these midterm election is whoever is angrier will usually go out to vote. The ones who are more satisfied generally will stay at home.

But if you're feeling better about things, that could mean there's fewer angrier, so the angry side that presumably would want to go against the incumbent party does not, and the people who are very happy with things maybe do consider going out and voting for the incumbent party.

It's a rule of thumb that's been all over the map and not consistent, but we are going to see if it plays out tonight beginning at 8:00 p.m., when FOX Business picks up our special live coverage of this to whenever in eight crucial states will have a lot to say about the direction, not only of this race, but this economy, and whether Democrats can make good on a promise and a commitment to take back the House and maybe the Senate.

We will explore that from all angles, as well as get real-time world market reaction to these developments. If you're think we're focused on this, you should see the attention this gets in the foreign press.

We will have more after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: CAVUTO: Do you think when the president weighs in, as he has right now, to disinviting the Philadelphia Eagles to come to the White House, or some of these other ancillary issues, they get the focus off legitimate issues, the way that people like Donald Trump or not, that kind of distraction -- and he is known for doing this a lot -- hurts his message?

(CROSSTALK)

NEWT GINGRICH (R), FORMER SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Yes. I think it does.

And, again, part of why I wrote "Trump's America" is to pull together in one volume the good things that are happening across the broad, whether it's energy or what have you.

I think President Trump at times clutters his own message, to his own disadvantage.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Proof-positive, this whole Philadelphia Eagles things today, that was the only thing reporters were interested in. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

QUESTION: Does he risk alienating key voters in that state by disinviting Eagles?

QUESTION: This isn't about the national anthem. It's about so few players coming in the end.

QUESTION: Does he bear zero responsibility for the players like the Warriors and the Cavs not wanting to come, and the Eagles bailing?

QUESTION: Is this about something more than the national anthem, something other than the national anthem?

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Look, if this wasn't a political stunt by the Eagles franchise, then they wouldn't have planned to attend the event, and then backed out at the last minute.

And if it wasn't a political stunt, then they wouldn't have attempted to reschedule the visit when they knew that the president was going to be overseas.

And if this wasn't a political stunt, they wouldn't have waited until Monday, well after 1,000 of their fans had traveled and taken time out of their schedules, to offer only a tiny handful of representatives to attend the event.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: That was virtually all of the line of questioning.

And you know who spoke right before Sarah did? Of course, a topic economic adviser delineating all the good economic news we have seen.

But, again, it falls on deaf ears when maybe the president himself grabs on to some of these other events that might be perfectly valid, but, again, get everyone's attention perfectly off the subject at hand, including an improving economy, which the president says fake news types don't report.

Francesca Chambers, of course, at those daily sessions, The Daily Mail White House correspondent.

Francesca, he curses his own message, does he not?

FRANCESCA CHAMBERS, THE DAILY MAIL: Well, and, yesterday, we saw something similar, where reporters repeatedly asked Sarah Sanders about the president's tweets about whether the special counsel was unconstitutional or not for that to have been put in place.

And so we have seen this several times. But, to that point today, it's not necessarily true that if reporters hadn't been asking about the Eagles not coming to the White House that the questions that would have been asked were things that the White House would have liked better.

We also heard things in the room today about Scott Pruitt, the EPA administrator and fresh allegations that he may have abused his power in office and taxpayer dollars.

CAVUTO: Is it your sense, though, that this whole football thing with the Eagles and whatever has created a furor and a distraction at a time the president probably wouldn't like it?

Whatever the merits of his argument and people standing for the national anthem, whatever, but he's a week ahead of crucial talks with the North Koreans. He does have a compelling argument to make about the economy, the markets, et cetera, and then this.

CHAMBERS: And you make a key point, Neil, about this summit with Kim Jong- un in Singapore.

That's something else that we barely heard about today, aside from the fact that he will meet Thursday at the White House with the Japanese prime minister, Shinzo Abe.

And didn't really have a chance today to ask about the president's tweets this morning about North Korea in which he said that he hopes and expects that something successful will come out of this today, Neil.

And so, again, though, sometimes, the questions, however, wouldn't necessarily be things that the White House wants to talk about more, because we also saw the president again tweeting this week about that Russia probe. And that's something that Sarah Sanders also didn't want to talk about today, deferring questions to the special counsel about that statement that the president may have dictated about his son Don Jr.'s meeting with the Russian lawyer at Trump Tower.

CAVUTO: Obviously, that has galvanized all the attention, not so much economic officials when they speak, which, as an economic reporter, I kind of bristle at, because I know people think I'm a nerd.

And I know I want to listen to what nerds say. I don't need it shoved back in my face that, you're so boring, Neil, we don't want to hear about it. But, again, that's what economic advisers get. Right? So, he's going to make a compelling argument, look at what is turning out right beneath you. But it's his boss himself that is distracting that attention.

CHAMBERS: Well, Kevin Hassett did say that he was going to try and cheer up reporters with some charts...

CAVUTO: Indeed.

CHAMBERS: ... to try and make it a little bit more interesting. Got a little bit of a visual representation there and a pamphlet held out, Neil.

But, again, this is something that, as you heard Newt Gingrich say, and even allies of the president, that when he does some of these tweets, it does distract from the message.

And we heard President Trump say -- or saw him say on Twitter last week that he was not going to focus on some of these things like Russia as much and he was going to focus on North Korea and that summit a little bit more, and then has continued to tweet about the Russia probe since then.

CAVUTO: All right.

Real quickly on this football thing, I'm beginning to think that when he got word that it was down to 10 or so Philadelphia Eagles going to this event, he preempted that, said, all right, this is ridiculous. And that was the catalyst, that it was such a small number.

Am I right?

CHAMBERS: Well, Sarah Sanders also brought that up today. She said that there were going to be what she called a tiny number.

We believe to be 10 to 12 were going to show up out of the more than 80 who were originally supposed to come.

CAVUTO: Right.

CHAMBERS: And they cited that as part of the reason, in addition to the national anthem and the kneeling, as a reason that the White House called off this event, but also what they described as the Eagles trying to move the event to a time that was inconvenient for the president, when he was scheduled to be overseas in Singapore for that summit, as a reason that this ultimately fell apart.

CAVUTO: Wow. All right.

Thank you very much, Francesca. Good seeing you again.

CHAMBERS: Thanks, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right.

In the meantime, who needs a summer vacation when you can work right through it to save your job? What Mitch McConnell is trying to orchestrate that has even some in his own party saying, really? Really?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right, we already talked about Mitch McConnell's plan to keep everybody, at least the Republicans, in the Capitol in the month of August during the typically otherwise four-week August recess, Wyoming Republican Senator, member of the Foreign Relations Committee, among many others, John Barrasso.

Senator, is this OK with you?

SEN. JOHN BARRASSO (R), WYOMING: Absolutely, Neil. I think it's an important thing to do.

We have been dealing with historic obstruction, deliberate delays by the Democrats just in terms of getting the president's team in place. So we want to be able to get more people confirmed.

But, additionally, you know, the president has been very clear. He's not going to sign another continuing resolution. We need to do individual appropriations bills. We have work to be done on behalf of the American people.

And in terms of the so-called recess, look, you know me. I'm a surgeon. I'm used to working nights, weekends, long hours. I think it's where we ought to be and the work we ought to be doing for the American people.

CAVUTO: How does that work, Senator?

Now, obviously, Mitch McConnell is the majority leader of the United States Senate. Can he compel the minority party, the Democrats, to stay in session as well?

BARRASSO: Well, no. Every senator makes their own decisions about when they're here or not.

CAVUTO: Including your own colleagues?

BARRASSO: Yes, but votes are called. And you can either be there to cast your vote or not, to represent your state or not on matters critical to the country.

And if individuals want to not be here, well, that's up to them. I'm going to be here doing the work. I know that Senator McConnell, as our leader, is going to be continuing on the floor putting up measures for votes, for discussions, for debates, and ultimately for votes. And that's how we plan to spend August.

CAVUTO: All right, some of your colleagues concerned that this robs them of time to be out on the campaign. Some of them are pretty vulnerable, not across the Senate, where the prospects are very different than House Republicans, but what are they saying?

BARRASSO: Well, there are consequences to people's actions.

And when you put that kind of delay deliberately on slowing down the president's nominations, we still have lots of work to be done. We want to get that work done. And if we haven't gotten it done so far, which we haven't, we need to make sure we get our work done in August.

CAVUTO: Where do you see things going right now among your colleagues and the likelihood to visit another second shot at the tax cut, one that would make permanent rate cuts for individuals?

I know Senator McConnell, when I last chatted with him, sir, seemed to not be too, too keen on it. Maybe he was thinking that it would help some of the most vulnerable Democrats who would get another shot at this, maybe vote for a phase two, when they didn't for phase one.

BARRASSO: Well, you know, Neil, I was home in Wyoming all last week during Memorial Day.

There's a confidence and an optimism in families, in working men and women all around Wyoming because of the tax bill. What we have seen is, they're keeping more of their hard-earned money, because taxes are lower.

Plus, they're seeing raises in their pay. Unemployment rates are down, which means people can wake up and know they have an opportunity for a job and to go forward, and the hope that comes from that. I would like to make all of these tax cuts permanent and work to that end between now and the end of this legislative session.

CAVUTO: When you look at what is happening in the Senate, where it's likely you guys could actually pick up seats, depending on how you want to look at the math, but a very different battle going on in the House, is it your sense that Republicans hold on, not only in the Senate, where, like I said, there's an argument to be made where you could pick up some seats, but in the House, that in some of these very dramatic races, that the edge to Democrats isn't what was the case?

BARRASSO: Well, the president's policies, in terms of taxes, in cutting taxes, cutting regulations, unleashing American energy, very unpopular around the United States, because the economy is so strong, and what that means to working families and having more money to spend.

CAVUTO: Well, it's not popular everywhere, right?

BARRASSO: So, it's...

CAVUTO: In some of the high-tax states, like New Jersey, where there are at least seven vulnerable Republican districts now, it's -- that tax cut is coming back to bite Republicans.

Now, it might be playing out in some other high-tax areas. Are you worried about that?

BARRASSO: Well, Neil, I want to make sure the president maintains his majority in the House and the Senate.

The Senate races are the ones that I have continued to focus on. As you know, I'm up for reelection this year, as are a number of my colleagues. But I think we have great opportunities.

And like you, I share the opinion that we have an opportunity to actually pick up seats to make it easier to get the president's agenda through the Senate. And that's what I'm working on through the fall.

CAVUTO: All right, Senator Barrasso, thank you very much. Very good seeing you again.

BARRASSO: Hey, thanks, Neil.

CAVUTO: All right.

Do any of you remember when Mark Zuckerberg was testifying before Congress and tried to lay down the new law here that there's nothing beyond what I'm telling you now that indicates problems or compromised data from anyone in this country?

A big old oops for the rich guy who founded a company, hoping that he would never encounter this type of controversy again. He has again.

We will explain next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: We're getting some very scary reports coming out of Hawaii now.

Hundreds of homes destroyed overnight with an eruption they didn't see coming. They see it now and they're worried about it now.

The latest from the Big Island -- after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right, this came out of nowhere, reports of hundreds of homes potentially destroyed by that volcano in Hawaii.

The latest right now from our own Jeff Paul.

Jeff, what are you hearing?

JEFF PAUL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Neil, this is something we were sort of expecting.

Emergency responders told us don't be surprised if this number of houses that are destroyed jumps a little bit, because obviously it is hard to tell really what's going on back there, as the lava covers this area.

But we're learning at least hundreds were destroyed overnight, and one of those homes belonging to Hawaii County's mayor. Now, the fortunately thing is that most of the people, we're hearing, in that area were already evacuated.

We haven't heard of any injuries or any deaths yet regarding this eruption from the Kilauea volcano. But just to give you the idea of just how much coverage area this volcano is now spreading out to and the lava, 7.7 square miles.

This is on top of the things that are happening at the summit of the volcano. We had another earthquake this morning, a 5.6-magnitude earthquake. So, it seems like the activity is continuing on.

But the lava, that is the main thing. It's not stopping. It keeps spreading out. It might flow. The lava fountains might not reach as high as they were. But the lava just keeps spreading. And it's pouring into the ocean right now.

CAVUTO: Scary stuff.

Jeff Paul, thank you very much, and keeping us updated.

Again, this doesn't seem to be beyond just real estate destruction, homes destroyed certainly, not a light matter for anyone, but, so far, no word beyond that of human casualties here. But we will keep you posted.

In the meantime, back in the continental United States and the friction over Facebook. This times, the heads of the Senate Commerce Committee sending a letter to CEO Mark Zuckerberg over a report, this one in The New York Times, that said the company might have given device makers data on users, among those device makers, Apple.

Lawmakers want answers by June 18.

Attorney Leeza Garber back with us on this stuff.

This is the problem that can ever go away for this company.

LEEZA GARBER, ATTORNEY: It can't go away.

And we're only recently learning the levels to which Facebook has been playing fast and loose with Americans' data privacy for years.

CAVUTO: So, what is this? They would have this data, they would give it to device makers, like Apple. Was there anything sinister going on, on these device makers; part?

GARBER: Part of the problem with this New York Times report on data sharing with device makers -- and you mentioned Apple -- it's also Amazon, BlackBerry, Microsoft, Samsung. The list keeps going, which is what is very scary.

But what happened is, not only was Facebook sharing data with applications like the Cambridge Analytica scandal that we saw in recent months, but now we have come to understand that they're sharing relationship status about information from the Facebook profiles, photographs, potentially even private messages with the device makers themselves.

And the way that they have been able to do this is by categorizing these hardware services as service providers. So, in that way, they're bypassing any sort of liability they had put in with the FTC, which had released a decree in 2011, saying, you can't play fast and loose anymore. You have to be explicit with users in gaining their consent.

CAVUTO: All right. But Tim Cook at Apple said he didn't do this kind of stuff and that Apple didn't do this kind of stuff.

If you're right about this, they did get this kind of stuff.

GARBER: These device makers definitely got access to this kind of data.

And whether they're storing it on their own servers, some of them have not responded to comment yet.

CAVUTO: Why would they want it?

GARBER: Why would they want it? They can monetize it. They can study the people that are buying their technology.

CAVUTO: But, again, Tim Cook said he didn't do that kind of stuff. So, did he lie?

GARBER: Mark Zuckerberg said he didn't do this kind of stuff either.

And you have to -- if you look back...

CAVUTO: But it was Tim Cook who was pointing and wagging his finger at Zuckerberg, saying that this is something that Apple would never do.

Am I missing something?

GARBER: You're not missing something.

I think the way that these key technological players are categorizing how they're taking data, what they're doing with it keeps changing. And that's part of the problem.

They're all in on this game, but they're creating the rules as they go along. And when you look at it, Facebook and these big tech companies have the keys to our data kingdom. But they're making copies and sharing them with everybody else.

So, how are we actually supposed to gain control of our data? It looks like it's impossible.

CAVUTO: You think they don't know this is going on?

GARBER: Facebook is saying they didn't know. And...

CAVUTO: So, that's even scarier.

(LAUGHTER)

GARBER: It is scary.

CAVUTO: Yes. Yes. Yes.

GARBER: They should understand exactly what's going on. But recent reports are saying, look how at far back this kind of corruption goes.

CAVUTO: Well, I don't get it. But it doesn't all jibe with the public comments out of all of these guys.

Leeza Garber, the attorney, cyber-security expert.

Speaking of cyber-security, it's basically the theme of this Bill Clinton book. He and Patterson came together to come up with a dramatic novel about the president missing. The president is missing.

Bill Clinton on a tour for this book might wish that he were -- after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The truth is, the hubbub was I got hot under the collar because of the way the questions were asked.

The suggestion was that I never apologized for what caused all the trouble for me 20 years ago.

So, the first point is, I did. I meant it then, and I meant it now.

I apologized to my family, to Monica Lewinsky and her family, and to the American people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: All right.

The president is sort of getting a lesson in going on a book tour and not assuming all sorts of other questions beyond the book would come out on that tour.

The president trying to dial back some of the comments he made in an angry exchange on NBC. But the fact of the matter is, he did, and some Democrats are wondering, do we need this right about now?

Democratic strategist Robin Biro, FOX News political analyst Gianno Caldwell, and The Washington Examiner's Emily Jashinsky.

Emily, whatever people think about what happened 20 years ago with Bill Clinton, it's all coming back 20 years later. Is that a good thing for Democrats?

EMILY JASHINSKY, THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER: Well, of course it's not a good thing for Democrats. And I think Democrats especially in red states know that.

I think there's more willingness among blue state Democrats, people in Maryland, people in New York, to use the Clintons on the campaign trail.

But think about this. If Bill Clinton is going to release a book and go on a publicity tour and campaign in the year of MeToo, in the MeToo era, he's going to face questions about Monica Lewinsky, of course.

But now that the precedent has been set in that NBC interview, that's one part of a broader story when it comes to Bill Clinton, because he has got Juanita Broaddrick. He's got other allegations of assault and harassment that he's going to face that will dog him if he goes out on the campaign trail for other people.

So, no, it's not good for Democrats. And red state Democrats should be running in the opposite direction of the Clintons, especially Bill Clinton, this year.

CAVUTO: Well, red state Republicans and other -- feel the same effect with Bill Clinton as they do with Donald Trump and vice versa. We live in an age where I don't know if this stuff resonates like it used to.

Gianno?

GIANNO CALDWELL, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: No, I don't think it's the same.

However, who would have thunk -- not thought -- who would have thunk that the Clintons, Bill and Hillary, would become the Republican Party's greatest assets?

You got a guy who has been off his game since the 2016 election who admitted that President Trump or then candidate Donald Trump was correct about the anxiety people felt, the anxiety, the economic angst that people felt. And those were a continuation of the Obama policies, which he I guess forgot that their playbook was four more years of the Obama policies.

So, when it comes to what he's doing, I have talked to Democrats nationally and both locally today. And they said they want to keep their distance from both Hillary and Bill, because it does nothing to benefit them for the upcoming midterms.

CAVUTO: Robin, when you are looking at this and the back and forth, and resurrecting Bill Clinton, even though this is a very unusual type of a book -- it's a work of fiction to talk about what would happen if the president just upped and disappeared -- it's a topical issue about cyber- security, something this president has been warning about.

But all that is falling on deaf ears.

ROBIN BIRO, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: It is.

And what people are hearing are 20-year-old accusations that are being brought back up. And as a red state Democrat, it's doing us no good. It's doing about as much good as it did Hillary Clinton when he had that meeting with Loretta Lynch on the tarmac. That was the singular moment, the defining moment where I knew we had serious trouble on our hands for that campaign.

And I don't want to trample on his First Amendment rights to free speech, but free speech has consequences. Just ask Roseanne Barr. We're each responsible for what we say and do. And he's not doing the party any favors rights now.

CAVUTO: When you look at this, and you think of what has happened since the emergence of the MeToo movement, Emily, and everything else, there's enough blame and questionable behavior to go around, and some questionable conduct to go around, where no one should be pointing fingers at anyone.

But, be that as it may, does this neutralize a worry that Republicans had about their own president, comments he has made, that it's all a soured lot? That's a bit of a generalization. But people just shrug their shoulders and say, all right, whoever is in charge, are they helping me out, whatever they are morally that I might or might not like?

JASHINSKY: Yes. And I think that's absolutely accurate.

There's really been no partisan bent to MeToo. And I think that's one of the most depressing things about it, right, is everybody is equally guilty. People in both parties have done despicable things and have mistreated women horribly.

And, so, yes, I don't think specifically there's a partisan benefit to either side when it comes to whether the MeToo allegations against certain people hurt a party, help a party.

But I do think, in specific races, where the Clintons are trying to target their efforts, you could absolutely see Bill Clinton coming into the local news market and just being an incredible distraction for vulnerable candidates.

Even for good candidates, he's going to be a huge distraction, the Clintons in general, but especially in this MeToo movement. In this MeToo moment, Bill Clinton is not helpful to anybody he's campaigning for, which is kind of unfortunate for him, because he does connect with red state voters in a way that other Democrats can't.

CAVUTO: Gianno?

CALDWELL: And to that point, if I could real quickly, really quickly, it's about his response, his reaction to it.

And I think that's what is going to get voters thinking twice about any candidate that he involves himself with. So you certainly don't want to be a candidate that has a fair shot to have Bill Clinton,who may have a hot collar when reporters are asking him questions, and take all the attention away from the work that you're going and put it squarely on himself.

JASHINSKY: Amen to that.

CAVUTO: Do you think, Robin, that candidates or voters, you know, are drawn to whoever is supporting another candidate? Does that make a difference in the scheme of things?

BIRO: Is that for me?

CAVUTO: Yes.

BIRO: You know, what I have got to say here is just that I have got to point out the obvious. I have a responsibility to.

That it seems like Bill Clinton and Donald Trump are cut from the same cloth. They're both pointing themselves as victims here. So, I'm starting to wonder if Donald Trump just didn't take up a lesson from Bill Clinton here. And no one is buying it.

CAVUTO: I don't know understand that means, but it sounds very profound.

I want to thank you all, seriously, guys.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: I'm kidding.

All right, we just don't know, but the back and forth goes on, and that book tour goes on.

By now, you have heard the sad news that the fashion designer Kate Spade died. She killed herself. Now the issue is not only why, but what was going on in the financial background?

We're on it after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right, fashion designer Kate Spade dead, found dead in her apartment morning, apparent suicide here. That's according to law enforcement officials.

They're still trying to unravel what happened and why.

FOX Business Network's Susan Li with the latest.

Hey, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Neil.

Tragic news in the fashion world today. The clothing and accessories designer known as Kate Spade found dead in her Park Avenue apartment this morning. New York police say that her housekeeper found Ms. Spade in her bedroom hanging from a red scarf tied to a doorknob.

As you can imagine, there's been an outpouring of grief and tributes coming in, including this tweet from her eponymous fashion label, Kate Spade: "The visionary founder of our brand has passed. Our thoughts are with her family at this incredibly heartbreaking time. We honor all the beauty she brought into this world."

Kate Spade really making her name in the late 1990s, making her mark with her functional, simple, yet stylish city bags. She actually won the Accessory Designer of the Year Award in 1998 from the CFDA.

Now, her label has gone on to grow not just for bags, but clothing, shoes and being sold all around the world. Kate Spade doesn't own her own label, though. She sold her company back in 1999 to the Neiman Marcus group.

But just to give you a sense how available her name and her brand has become, Kate Spade name was sold to the owners of the Coach and Stuart Weitzman brands back in 2017 for nearly $2.5 billion.

Kate was just 55 years old. She's survived by her husband and her daughter.

Ivanka Trump also tweeting in response to this loss today, saying that: "Kate Spade's tragic passing is a painful reminder that we never truly know another's pain or burden that they carry."

The National Suicide Prevention Line that -- can be reached on the number that you see on your screen there -- Neil, back to you.

CAVUTO: Susan, thank you very, very much.

We will have more right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: We are getting word -- I kid you not -- this from our colleagues at The New York Post -- that NBA star turned Kim Jong-un soul mate, as they call him, Dennis Rodman, will be in Singapore ahead of the president's summit with the North Korean dictator.

In fact, he might in fact be part of this ongoing process.

When I think of who could figure out what the heck this means, I go to my buddy, my good, good friend for so many years Charles Payne to put him on the spot, and his career and as well.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: What the heck? What does that mean?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, it either means Peter Navarro is out or Wilbur Ross. No.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Exactly. Dennis Rodman is now...

PAYNE: Now we know we have got a deal.

Sounds like some sort of publicity stunt.

CAVUTO: Right.

PAYNE: I think we better wait to get more information on that.

But it certainly sounds like someone having a good time. He's going to get a lot of publicity. So, maybe if he is wearing a pair of Skechers or something like that, we will see what is going on.

CAVUTO: And he does -- he's one of the few Americans who has a relationship and who has an ongoing one with Kim Jong-un.

And I'm just wondering, the president probably can use all the friends he can get for this big meeting. But a week from today, the pressure is on, the timetable is on. It's one day. And that's it.

PAYNE: Kim Jong-un went to school in the West. He obviously admired Western culture, including basketball.

And a lot of people say that the Olympics, going and watching what's happening, that maybe, just maybe he does want something for his people. And I think the administration must believe that too, because President Trump over and over again has made these overtures about hardworking North Koreans, about the opportunities and about the investments that are going to pour in from China, Japan, South Korea.

He's made his overture very many times. So, maybe someone in the White House believes also that that's another strong economic -- a strong negotiating point.

CAVUTO: What you said is very deep and profound. What you are missing is that maybe he just wants a fast food outlet.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Right, because that was one of the things that we were sort of dangling, right?

PAYNE: Well, guess what? You could get a McD's. You could get a KFC. You can get it all.

You know what? Get you a Starbucks. We could throw it all in there. This is like Ron Popeil. But, wait, there's more, you know?

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: The onus does seem to be on us, though, to provide a lot of money.

Now, the president has already made clear, and lowered expectations, that don't expect a lot of that, and don't expect us to sort of be the sugar daddy here.

But I am wondering what we would offer in return for this kingdom to start denuclearizing.

PAYNE: Right.

I have asked that question of all the experts, and none have given me an answer. But there is no doubt the nukes are North Korea's -- they're their only currency they have. They make a few bucks making those big bronze statues for other dictators, but besides that, it's the only currency that they have.

To give that up, you need a combination of guaranteed safety and major economic injections. And so it's going to be a big number, I think. But I think the world will say the number can't be too big, if you get rid of this most dangerous part of planet.

CAVUTO: Separately, we got signs that we have lost -- that the Chinese are offering to buy up $70 billion worth of agricultural goods from us.

Not much reaction. Maybe some people didn't take it seriously. But that would be quite a coup for the president, were it to pass.

PAYNE: I think a lot of other presidents would've taken that, ran with it, spiked the ball, and declared victory.

President Trump is playing a very, very tough game here. It's a strong, strong, tough, tough game.

CAVUTO: So, he didn't respond one way or the other, right?

PAYNE: I think they -- I think it's a good overture. And I think it's -- listen, he threw out some larger numbers than that.

But $70 billion is huge. Maybe they will work on the technology side. I think, ultimately, we are going to hear some sort of number of $100 billion talked about, and probably a combination of lower tariffs and the ability to open up their markets.

But also you have got to get something on the technology side, particularly since President Trump revived ZTE.

CAVUTO: All right, Charles, thank you very much.

PAYNE: You got it. Thanks.

CAVUTO: You were ready for that Rodman thing, unfortunately. I thought I would kind of zing you with that one.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: That's a free lead for your fine show tonight.

PAYNE: I'm thinking about it.

CAVUTO: About an hour from now.

PAYNE: I'm calling the crew right now.

CAVUTO: You go. Go, baby, go.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: That is the lead, 6:00 p.m. for his fine show, "Making Money With Charles Payne."

All right, and we will be making a lot of coverage for you tonight on all these key states, eight of them right now that have very crucial primaries, including California, where they have redone the math on the electoral process.

It starts at 8:00 p.m. We will go to whenever and however long it takes to give you the -- sort of the place setting for the midterm elections.

Now, 12 of those races are in safe districts that Democrats think they have a very good chance of taking with the right candidate. We will find out tonight.

See you in about three hours.

END

urn:contentItem:5SGV-4781-JB20-G0FW-00000-00Fashion Designer Found Dead in Apparent Suicide; Bill Clinton Under Fire; Primary Election Day; Interview With Wyoming Senator John Barrasso2018-06-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:48:57ZLexisNexisYOUR WORLD WITH NEIL CAVUTO4:00 PM ESTEmily Jashinsky, Eliza Collins, Shelby Holliday, Robin Biro, Francesca Chambers, Leeza Garber, John BarrassoNEWSInternational060502cb.140Fashion Designer Found Dead in Apparent Suicide; Bill Clinton Under Fire; Primary Election Day; Interview With Wyoming Senator John BarrassoJeff Paul, Hillary Vaughn, Connell McShane, Deirdre Bolton, Gianno Caldwell, Charles Payne, Susan Li, Neil Cavuto

NEIL CAVUTO, HOST: This is as big as it gets before the big midterm Election Day.

The race on in eight states holding crucial primaries today, among them, California and New Jersey, which could hold the key to whether Democrats regain the House of Representatives this November.

In California alone, more than $108 million has reportedly been spent on a very crowded congressional field of races, to say nothing of the gubernatorial battle.

The outcome could have a huge impact on everything from the economy, to trade, to taxes, and possibly slam the brakes on the president's agenda. Talk about a lot at stake.

Welcome. I'm Neil Cavuto, and this is "Your World."

We're all over it with FOX Business Network's Deirdre Bolton on the seats that Democrats are trying to flip. There are quite a few. Hillary Vaughn in Orange County, California, on how some win-or-take-all primaries could leave some Democrats flipping out. And FOX Business Network's Connell McShane in Iowa on if the president's trade policies could be a big flop for Republicans.

We begin with Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Neil.

Well, National Democrats tell me this California primary is make or break. And voting is under way right now in Huntington Beach, California, one of the districts Democrats poured millions of dollars into. They have been counting on a blue wave hitting California to add to their tally of seats they want to flip across the country to secure the House majority in November.

But national Democrats tell me they're worried they could be left off the ballot entirely because too many of them are running. So, the DCCC has had to dump millions in the races, ask candidates to get out of the race.

But still, they're worried that it won't be enough. They're targeting 10 seats in the race, four right here in Orange County, two open seats from Republican representatives retiring, Darrell Issa and Ed Royce.

But they're also targeting two seats that Republican incumbents are trying to hold on to, Congressman Rohrabacher and Mimi Walters.

Here's why, because these four districts voted for Hillary Clinton in 2016. So, Democrats saw an opening they want to use for their advantage in 2018.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DANA ROHRABACHER (R), CALIFORNIA: I'm up against two millionaires, and we know that there's billionaires who are financing most of what the Democratic Party does. So the public is going to wake up to that. And it's not in their -- the interests of hardworking people to support some political clique that is trying to basically control the state and control their lives.

I'm very confident and the Republican Party is about ready to surge back in California, as compared to this blue wave that we're being told is coming.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: Here in Huntington Beach, Rohrabacher is not only fending off Democrats, but also a fellow Republican in this primary.

Republican Scott Baugh is close friends with Rohrabacher, but he's also fighting for his seat. He says it's good for Republicans, because if they are the two that face off in November, that would leave Democrats off the ballot entirely.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: You're challenging Rohrabacher, a fellow Republican. So, what I want to know is, how do you think that actually helps Republicans on primary night today?

SCOTT BAUGH (R), CALIFORNIA CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: Well, are you kidding me?

If the Republicans have two in the playoffs, two in the general election, it means that this seat is removed from the Democrat calculation altogether. They can't win the seat, it's impossible, because they don't have a candidate in the general elections.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: A Democratic lockout could be a huge nightmare for Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who has said the pathway to victory for them runs through California right here.

But I talked to Democratic candidates that they have hand-picked and they're still not ready to vocalize their support for a potential Speaker Pelosi run if the Democrats were successful to win the majority in November -- Neil.

CAVUTO: All right, Hillary Vaughn, thank you very, very much.

To put California and some of these other states in perspective, California and New Jersey alone have 12 Republican seats now held that could easily flip. That is about half the number that Democrats would need alone to regain control of the House of Representatives.

That's how much is at stake in just two prominent states. But that's not all that is up for grabs.

FOX Business Network's Deirdre Bolton keeping track of some of the tossup races and issues that could have a huge impact.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Neil, there's a lot, so California is so important.

And, I mean, experts are really saying these primaries are going to potentially be make-or-break contests for both parties. So here's the short list, the ones that we're really focused on in the Golden State.

So, the 10th Congressional District, the incumbent there, Republican Jeff Denham, that is his photo there. Now, in the 2016 presidential election, Secretary Clinton beat President Trump by three percentage points in that district.

So, another that we're following, the 25th Congressional District. The incumbent there, Republican Steve Knight. And if you go back to the presidential election, you had a 7 percentage point gain by the Democrats, and that was of course Hillary Clinton vs. President Trump.

In California's 48th Congressional District, the incumbent there, Republican Dana Rohrabacher, there is his photo there. And if you go back to the presidential election, it's only a 2 percentage point lead that Hillary Clinton had over President Trump.

Immigration, that is one of the most volatile issues for all of these races. That may motivate voters to show up. California is home to more immigrants, legal, undocumented, than any other state in the U.S. It's a huge issue there.

Also, of those three key races that we highlighted, they are all ones that have sanctuary city status. So, people are very clear either on one side or the other particularly about illegal immigration.

The other big issue that may motivate California voters is the threat of trade wars. So, California grows tons of almonds, beans, milk, pork, some of which is exported. California as a whole produces and sells more than $15 billion worth of agricultural products.

Now, in that 10th Congressional District, all by itself, more than $2.5 billion of goods are sold there. So, one of our 50 states, of course California. But, as a stand-alone country, like this trivia point, it would be the world's sixth largest economy.

Neil, you mentioned those three seats in New Jersey. And, of course, one of the things that the Republicans are going to be fighting against are the Trump administration's tax plans, which hurt a lot of real estate owners and real estate investors in New Jersey.

CAVUTO: Right.

BOLTON: There's a lot of people pretty bitter about that. And some calls I made, they said, listen, if you're independent, if you're on the line, that actually may help Democrats, if for no other reason than revenge of what people feel in their own pockets.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Yes, their deductions were dramatically limited.

BOLTON: Yes.

CAVUTO: All right, Deirdre, thank you very, very much.

In the meantime, will the economy trump fears of a trade war in today's primaries?

Let's get the read from Connell McShane, who has been talking to farmers out in Iowa, USA Today's congressional reporter Eliza Collins, and The Wall Street Journal's Shelby Holliday.

Connell, out there in farmland, of course, they're surprised. Big backers of Donald Trump in general, but concerned about a trade war that could have the Chinese not buying a lot of the stuff they produce, right?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes.

Neil, what is interesting on this very program yesterday, as you remember, Neil, we had a farmer named Ron Heck on the show from here in Iowa. And he was talking about some of the concerns.

But what I will say after spending a couple days out here on the ground -- and this is just anecdotal, speaking to Heck and some others this morning out at a Dubuque diner about this very subject -- is just because you assume that one thing is true, in other words, a trade war policy or a protectionist policy from the White House is going to hurt somebody, the president, Republicans, politically, doesn't necessarily mean it's going to play out that way.

Again, it's just anecdotal. But in speaking to people, the president, among his supporters, Neil, he has built up a lot of equity with tax cuts, with deregulatory policies, where that support seems to still be solid from the people who supported him in the past. And they're cutting him some slack and willing to see how this trade debate and trade discussion will play out over a matter of time.

I have been a little bit surprised by it.

CAVUTO: And as you reported earlier as well, the Chinese offered a -- maybe a first opening salvo here to buy $70 billion of U.S. agricultural- related products here. So, that could ease a lot of this angst if it turns out to be a concession on the Chinese part. There's been no follow-up. We will see.

You know, Eliza, when you look at what's going on here, the view had been not too long ago that we face a blue wave here, that Democrats were certainly going to gain a lot of seats, enough to tip the balance of power in the either House and/or Senate, less likely the Senate, still possibly the House.

And then along came an improving economy, along came a startlingly good jobs report, and now they're not so sure. What is the latest read?

ELIZA COLLINS, USA TODAY: Exactly.

The economy's improvement and the steady, strong economy has really helped Republicans. They feel good about their tax cuts, although they have not been -- like we have analyzed advertisements. That's not been the number one issue they have been talking about, which is a little bit interesting.

But it's certainly helping them. There is concern from Republicans here at the Capitol about these impending trade wars, so much concern, that they're actually talking about a bill right now that could basically give Congress the authority to vote up or down the president's proposed tariffs in the future based on national security.

We don't know if that has enough votes right now, but it's certainly being discussed. And something interesting is, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has not ruled it out of being added or at least voted on a separate piece of legislation.

So, he's not stopping it, which does say that Republicans here are concerned about the effects of a possible trade war.

CAVUTO: We should also mention, and she did, you know, Shelby, this idea that Republicans, Mitch McConnell are concerned enough about getting more stuff done, that they're going to be working through the August recess, or at least that's the plan.

What is the political fallout of that?

SHELBY HOLLIDAY, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Well, politically, some of these Republicans will not be at home in their districts.

That means less time on the campaign trail meeting voters, shaking hands. But, on the flip side, if they get a lot done and they accomplish things Republicans want to see them accomplish, it could be a good thing.

So, right now, kind of hard to say. I will say that it's impossible to know what will be top of mind for voters come November. The Trump presidency seems to change news cycles every hour, if not every day.

But if economy is top of mind -- I was looking through some Wall Street polls -- and most voters feel that the Republicans are in a better place to handle the economy, things like taxes, trade, the deficit.

However, if an issue like immigration or health care is top of mind for voters, that could hurt the GOP.

And I would add the trade -- the question about a trade war has thrown a huge wrench into this, because if there's a trade war and if most voters start to think that Democrats could handle the economy better, if they start to think Democrats would be better on trade, then you see this huge list of issues that most voters would feel Democrats are better on.

And that could really threaten Republicans come November in the midterms.

CAVUTO: All right, guys, I want to all very, very much.

Just a reminder here, the typical rule of thumb in these midterm election is whoever is angrier will usually go out to vote. The ones who are more satisfied generally will stay at home.

But if you're feeling better about things, that could mean there's fewer angrier, so the angry side that presumably would want to go against the incumbent party does not, and the people who are very happy with things maybe do consider going out and voting for the incumbent party.

It's a rule of thumb that's been all over the map and not consistent, but we are going to see if it plays out tonight beginning at 8:00 p.m., when FOX Business picks up our special live coverage of this to whenever in eight crucial states will have a lot to say about the direction, not only of this race, but this economy, and whether Democrats can make good on a promise and a commitment to take back the House and maybe the Senate.

We will explore that from all angles, as well as get real-time world market reaction to these developments. If you're think we're focused on this, you should see the attention this gets in the foreign press.

We will have more after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: CAVUTO: Do you think when the president weighs in, as he has right now, to disinviting the Philadelphia Eagles to come to the White House, or some of these other ancillary issues, they get the focus off legitimate issues, the way that people like Donald Trump or not, that kind of distraction -- and he is known for doing this a lot -- hurts his message?

(CROSSTALK)

NEWT GINGRICH (R), FORMER SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: Yes. I think it does.

And, again, part of why I wrote "Trump's America" is to pull together in one volume the good things that are happening across the broad, whether it's energy or what have you.

QUESTION: Does he risk alienating key voters in that state by disinviting Eagles?

In the meantime, who needs a summer vacation when you can work right through it to save your job? What Mitch McConnell is trying to orchestrate that has even some in his own party saying, really? Really?

CAVUTO: All right, we already talked about Mitch McConnell's plan to keep everybody, at least the Republicans, in the Capitol in the month of August during the typically otherwise four-week August recess, Wyoming Republican Senator, member of the Foreign Relations Committee, among many others, John Barrasso.

Senator, is this OK with you?

SEN. JOHN BARRASSO (R), WYOMING: Absolutely, Neil. I think it's an important thing to do.

We have been dealing with historic obstruction, deliberate delays by the Democrats just in terms of getting the president's team in place. So we want to be able to get more people confirmed.

But, additionally, you know, the president has been very clear. He's not going to sign another continuing resolution. We need to do individual appropriations bills. We have work to be done on behalf of the American people.

And in terms of the so-called recess, look, you know me. I'm a surgeon. I'm used to working nights, weekends, long hours. I think it's where we ought to be and the work we ought to be doing for the American people.

CAVUTO: How does that work, Senator?

Now, obviously, Mitch McConnell is the majority leader of the United States Senate. Can he compel the minority party, the Democrats, to stay in session as well?

BARRASSO: Well, no. Every senator makes their own decisions about when they're here or not.

CAVUTO: Including your own colleagues?

BARRASSO: Yes, but votes are called. And you can either be there to cast your vote or not, to represent your state or not on matters critical to the country.

And if individuals want to not be here, well, that's up to them. I'm going to be here doing the work. I know that Senator McConnell, as our leader, is going to be continuing on the floor putting up measures for votes, for discussions, for debates, and ultimately for votes. And that's how we plan to spend August.

CAVUTO: All right, some of your colleagues concerned that this robs them of time to be out on the campaign. Some of them are pretty vulnerable, not across the Senate, where the prospects are very different than House Republicans, but what are they saying?

BARRASSO: Well, there are consequences to people's actions.

And when you put that kind of delay deliberately on slowing down the president's nominations, we still have lots of work to be done. We want to get that work done. And if we haven't gotten it done so far, which we haven't, we need to make sure we get our work done in August.

CAVUTO: Where do you see things going right now among your colleagues and the likelihood to visit another second shot at the tax cut, one that would make permanent rate cuts for individuals?

I know Senator McConnell, when I last chatted with him, sir, seemed to not be too, too keen on it. Maybe he was thinking that it would help some of the most vulnerable Democrats who would get another shot at this, maybe vote for a phase two, when they didn't for phase one.

BARRASSO: Well, you know, Neil, I was home in Wyoming all last week during Memorial Day.

There's a confidence and an optimism in families, in working men and women all around Wyoming because of the tax bill. What we have seen is, they're keeping more of their hard-earned money, because taxes are lower.

Plus, they're seeing raises in their pay. Unemployment rates are down, which means people can wake up and know they have an opportunity for a job and to go forward, and the hope that comes from that. I would like to make all of these tax cuts permanent and work to that end between now and the end of this legislative session.

CAVUTO: When you look at what is happening in the Senate, where it's likely you guys could actually pick up seats, depending on how you want to look at the math, but a very different battle going on in the House, is it your sense that Republicans hold on, not only in the Senate, where, like I said, there's an argument to be made where you could pick up some seats, but in the House, that in some of these very dramatic races, that the edge to Democrats isn't what was the case?

BARRASSO: Well, the president's policies, in terms of taxes, in cutting taxes, cutting regulations, unleashing American energy, very unpopular around the United States, because the economy is so strong, and what that means to working families and having more money to spend.

CAVUTO: Well, it's not popular everywhere, right?

BARRASSO: So, it's...

CAVUTO: In some of the high-tax states, like New Jersey, where there are at least seven vulnerable Republican districts now, it's -- that tax cut is coming back to bite Republicans.

Now, it might be playing out in some other high-tax areas. Are you worried about that?

BARRASSO: Well, Neil, I want to make sure the president maintains his majority in the House and the Senate.

The Senate races are the ones that I have continued to focus on. As you know, I'm up for reelection this year, as are a number of my colleagues. But I think we have great opportunities.

And like you, I share the opinion that we have an opportunity to actually pick up seats to make it easier to get the president's agenda through the Senate. And that's what I'm working on through the fall.

CAVUTO: All right, Senator Barrasso, thank you very much. Very good seeing you again.

BARRASSO: Hey, thanks, Neil.

In the meantime, back in the continental United States and the friction over Facebook. This times, the heads of the Senate Commerce Committee sending a letter to CEO Mark Zuckerberg over a report, this one in The New York Times, that said the company might have given device makers data on users, among those device makers, Apple.

Lawmakers want answers by June 18.

Attorney Leeza Garber back with us on this stuff.

This is the problem that can ever go away for this company.

LEEZA GARBER, ATTORNEY: It can't go away.

And we're only recently learning the levels to which Facebook has been playing fast and loose with Americans' data privacy for years.

CAVUTO: So, what is this? They would have this data, they would give it to device makers, like Apple. Was there anything sinister going on, on these device makers; part?

GARBER: Part of the problem with this New York Times report on data sharing with device makers -- and you mentioned Apple -- it's also Amazon, BlackBerry, Microsoft, Samsung. The list keeps going, which is what is very scary.

But what happened is, not only was Facebook sharing data with applications like the Cambridge Analytica scandal that we saw in recent months, but now we have come to understand that they're sharing relationship status about information from the Facebook profiles, photographs, potentially even private messages with the device makers themselves.

And the way that they have been able to do this is by categorizing these hardware services as service providers. So, in that way, they're bypassing any sort of liability they had put in with the FTC, which had released a decree in 2011, saying, you can't play fast and loose anymore. You have to be explicit with users in gaining their consent.

CAVUTO: All right. But Tim Cook at Apple said he didn't do this kind of stuff and that Apple didn't do this kind of stuff.

If you're right about this, they did get this kind of stuff.

GARBER: These device makers definitely got access to this kind of data.

And whether they're storing it on their own servers, some of them have not responded to comment yet.

CAVUTO: Why would they want it?

GARBER: Why would they want it? They can monetize it. They can study the people that are buying their technology.

CAVUTO: But, again, Tim Cook said he didn't do that kind of stuff. So, did he lie?

GARBER: Mark Zuckerberg said he didn't do this kind of stuff either.

And you have to -- if you look back...

CAVUTO: But it was Tim Cook who was pointing and wagging his finger at Zuckerberg, saying that this is something that Apple would never do.

Am I missing something?

GARBER: You're not missing something.

I think the way that these key technological players are categorizing how they're taking data, what they're doing with it keeps changing. And that's part of the problem.

They're all in on this game, but they're creating the rules as they go along. And when you look at it, Facebook and these big tech companies have the keys to our data kingdom. But they're making copies and sharing them with everybody else.

So, how are we actually supposed to gain control of our data? It looks like it's impossible.

CAVUTO: You think they don't know this is going on?

GARBER: Facebook is saying they didn't know. And...

CAVUTO: So, that's even scarier.

(LAUGHTER)

GARBER: It is scary.

CAVUTO: Yes. Yes. Yes.

GARBER: They should understand exactly what's going on. But recent reports are saying, look how at far back this kind of corruption goes.

All right, and we will be making a lot of coverage for you tonight on all these key states, eight of them right now that have very crucial primaries, including California, where they have redone the math on the electoral process.

It starts at 8:00 p.m. We will go to whenever and however long it takes to give you the -- sort of the place setting for the midterm elections.

Now, 12 of those races are in safe districts that Democrats think they have a very good chance of taking with the right candidate. We will find out tonight.

See you in about three hours.
